name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, Honourable Members, the Commission takes note of this Resolution objecting to specifications for titanium dioxide adopted by the European Parliament. It considers that the draft Commission Regulation is in line with the implementing powers conferred on the Commission by Regulation (EC) No 1333/2008. The Standing Committee has given a favourable opinion on the draft act and the Council has already decided not to oppose it. The Commission regrets that the European Parliament has rejected this measure, which is based on the scientific assessment of the European Food Safety Authority. If adopted, the measure would have resulted in an improved level of safety regarding the use of this food additive and better control of the products present on the market, thus allowing a better enforcement by Member States of the legislation. Such decisions by the European Parliament undermine the EU’s well-established science-based approach to food safety.  – Madam President, Honourable Members, the Commission takes note of this resolution objecting to maximum levels of acrylamide, adopted by the European Parliament. It considers that the draft Commission Regulation is in line with the implementing powers conferred on the Commission by Regulation (EEC) No 315/93 aiming to protect public health. The Standing Committee has given a favourable opinion by unanimity on the draft act and the Council has not opposed it. The Commission regrets that the European Parliament has rejected this measure, which protects health and is based on the scientific assessment of the European Food Safety Authority. The levels of acrylamide raise concerns with respect to its carcinogenic effects, including for infants and young children. If adopted, the EU would have become the first region in the world to set legally-binding maximum levels of acrylamide and would have resulted in an improved level of food safety for infants and young children. There are every day foods on the market containing acrylamide above the proposed maximum levels, but in the absence of this Regulation, there will be no basis to remove them from the market. Consequently, children and infants will continue being exposed to levels of acrylamide, which are scientifically considered not safe. The Commission wants to emphasise that additional data are being collected and further consultations are being held with a view to extending the measure to other food categories. As such, this objection to this first step might undermine and delay the ongoing work on setting maximum levels for acrylamide in other relevant food categories. The Commission calls on the European Parliament to follow the European Union’s well-established science-based approach to food safety. Thank you President, thank you Honourable Members. President, Honourable Members. The Commission disagrees with the omission of Article 2(1) TFEU as legal basis of the decision empowering France to negotiate with the United Kingdom. While Article 91 TFEU empowers the Union to adopt acts of transport policy, the legislator is warranted powers to authorise Member States to act in the Union’s stead in an area of exclusive Union competence only under Article 2(1) TFEU. The decision can therefore be adopted only on the basis of both provisions. Thank you President, thank you Honourable Members.

name: Nicola BEER
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission's statement on combating money laundering on the basis of the FinCEN files (2020/2812(RSP)). I would like to remind colleagues once again that all the debates in this part-session do not accept spontaneous speeches or blue cards.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission and my colleague Valdis Dombrovskis, who is unable to be here today, welcomes today’s debate.  Dirty money is highly mobile. Time and again, we see criminals move it around the world with relative ease. Each new money-laundering revelation sparks more public anger. It erodes trust in our banks and financial institutions, in our authorities and our governments.  The FinCEN case we are discussing today confirms the Commission’s own reports and risk assessments from July 2019 that money laundering is a global challenge that demands a global response. If we are to succeed in fighting global cross-border crime, then we must all pull together and work with global partners, such as the United States, on closing loopholes. EU countries must also join forces to make the system less open to abuse. Member States acting alone are simply not up to the task of addressing a global challenge of such magnitude. The FinCEN files illustrate the vast scale of the problem. The European Union has to act decisively and collectively, with the European approach to supervision, a European approach to financial intelligence coordination. Dirty money should have nowhere to hide. Before the summer break on 8 July, the Commission outlined in this House the action plan for a comprehensive Union policy on preventing money laundering and terrorist financing, which the Commission adopted on 7 May 2020. It is now critical that we deliver on our action plan.  The FinCEN files are yet another illustration of why it is essential that financial institutions and other private sector entities detect suspicious financial flows and report their suspicions to the relevant authorities. They also highlight how important it is that national financial intelligence units have adequate tools and the capacity to process and analyse this information. These are all issues addressed in our action plan with a number of concrete actions proposed.  The Commission is also looking much more closely at how Member States implement the anti-money laundering directives so that our rules are effective on the ground. Enforcement is not only about ensuring the complete or correct transposition of the 4th and 5th Anti-Money Laundering Directives: enforcement is also about ensuring that anti-money laundering directives are effectively implemented.  The Commission recently sent questionnaires to some Member States. We will actively follow up on our findings. We will investigate ongoing problems and we will not hesitate to take legal steps if needed. There must be no divergences nor systematic weaknesses that could attract criminals. The European Union Supervisory System is only as strong as its weakest link.  We know that national supervisors cannot do this alone, which is why our action plan proposed EU-level supervision. For European Union supervision to work efficiently and seamlessly, we need an integrated system where national supervisors and the European Union Supervisor work effectively together, including by carrying out joint examinations here, and European Union anti-money laundering authorities would need to be equipped with significant and direct supervisory powers regarding the most risky obliged entities.  While the financial sector should be our initial priority, the European Union would need to progressively and significantly increase supervision of the non-financial sector. The anti-money laundering authority should also check that all national supervisors have adequate resources and powers to carry out their task. This could include on-site checks and would be the best way to monitor and make sure that the rules are applied effectively and consistently across the European Union.  The FinCEN case made it also clear that the increased number of reports submitted to the financial intelligence units puts pressure on their resources. We intend to put a coordination and support mechanism in place to support financial intelligence units in the European Union as a first step. This is vital for improving the detection of suspicious cash flows, especially those with a cross-border dimension, and for developing better analytical tools. Concretely we plan to support financial intelligence units in carrying out joint analyses, developing standards for reporting suspicious transactions, and providing IT assistance and support for exchanging financial information. The momentum to act decisively is with us. Everyone – authorities, stakeholders and citizens alike – expects the Union to act and ensure the stability and integrity of the Union’s financial system. We are grateful to this Parliament for setting the tone with its resolution last July. The time to act is now. We must close the door on dirty money decisively. The Commission is fully committed to presenting ambitious proposals in the first quarter of 2021 and counts on your full support.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Madam Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. The FinCEN files show something that we discussed with Mr Dombrovskis only a few months ago in this round – Mrs Euica, you have pointed this out. And what has changed since then? Nothing. I very much regret – and I say this right at the beginning of this debate – that the Council is once again not represented. After all, where do we have the core problems? In the Member States. In those Member States that are unable to transpose what they decide here at European level into applicable law at home. I am very grateful to the Commission, which is now also taking infringement proceedings against Member States. The deadline for implementing the 5th Anti-Money Laundering Directive was 1 January 2020, in the good old days before Corona. So you could have done it all. So far, only 17 Member States have reported full transposition. I hope that the Commission will also examine whether the report is true. The rest has only partially implemented, that is nine, and one did not even consider it necessary to report what he has done, namely Cyprus. These are the problems we are facing here in Europe. Problem number two – and this is not news either, but we have debated this many times: financial supervisory authorities are not in a position to deal adequately with criminals. The suspension of the money laundering unit in the European Banking Authority was an emergency solution, is an emergency solution and must be replaced by a permanent solution with an authority that also has legal intervention.  Money laundering must not only be an administrative offence at European level, but must be a criminal offence. To achieve this, we must create the legal conditions. The European way must be that money laundering in Europe has no chance. For the rest of the world, we can only impose restrictions, but they should follow the European example.

name: Eero HEINÄLUOMA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, USD 2 000 billion: this is almost twice the amount of the seven—year MFF and three times the value of the recovery and resilience instrument and, at the same time, it is at least 30 times the Finnish annual budget. Suspicious activity reports which were recently leaked concern transactions worth USD 2 000 billion. Banks must fill in one of these reports if they are worried one of their clients might be up to no good. The report is sent to the authorities. Despite these alarms, banks still often execute these transactions. Again, it is thanks to the great work of investigation journalists that this scandal is revealed.  It demonstrates once again that the existing Anti—Money Laundering (AML) system simply does not work. It is a Swiss cheese, full of holes.  For a long time, my group has been calling for a uniform regulatory framework, an AML regulation. Regulatory clarity and certainty is needed for the public sector and for industry. We also need stricter rules around rules on consumer due diligence and beneficial ownership transparency.  Stronger EU supervision is urgently needed too. Whether we need a new EU agency or extending the powers of the European Banking Authority is in a way less important, as long as the job is done far much better than today. Therefore, the supervisor should get enough resources, staff and independence and, of course, more EU supervision will only work provided there is good cooperation with the national competent authorities, as they are on the ground. Supervising can only be done properly provided data around suspicious transactions flow easily cross—border. Therefore, we need a European Union Finance Intelligence Unit. Detecting and supervising suspicious cases is one thing, tackling and sanctioning is something else.  I realise this is a very sensitive field of crime enforcement, and Member States like to keep control. Nonetheless, if we want to be serious in tackling AML, we need more deterring sanctions. Imposing big fines is all well and good, but I have not the impression that it changes fundamentally a culture. Here a stronger role for Europol is really needed.

name: Ramona STRUGARIU
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, 2 100 suspicious activity reports and more than USD 2 trillion in transactions: these are stunning numbers. The leaks revealed suspicious transactions at Deutsche Bank. Russian criminals and money launderers working for terrorist groups allegedly laundered money through the Moscow branch. The name of Vladimir Putin’s cousin, Igor Putin, is also linked to such a transaction.  Another leak revealed a transaction of USD 31 million between two offshore companies. The first one, with an account at Piraeus Bank, is owned by a person involved in arms trafficking for the Islamic State, and the other, with an account in the state-controlled Bulgarian Development Bank, is owned by a notorious Bulgarian arms dealer.  All of this is happening under the eyes of the financial intelligence units, of the European banking authorities, of the European Central Bank (ECB), of the law—enforcement national authorities. Can I ask how is it possible that we see such impressive amounts of money transferred to safe places through the banking system? Basically, there is zero time to waste, and if we want to efficiently fight money laundering, we need full judicial cooperation in criminal matters; we need an anti-money laundering (AML) regulation, which we have been talking about for a long time; we need full transparency on beneficial ownership, which we have been talking about for a long time; cooperation with national authorities as well, but a truly functioning supervisory body. This is if we really want to fight money laundering. If not, it will never happen.

name: Joachim KUHS
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for We are here today, and I think we all agree that money laundering is not possible. But we are shedding crocodile tears here about how awful it all is and that we have already made so many rules, but that the rules are not being implemented. I believe that we have to say that there is no point in just combating the symptoms. There is no point in always only tackling money laundering, because we must tackle what lies behind it. Only in this way can we drain this swamp that is rising here. We must combat the criminal activities that lead to this dirty money. And it is only when we have achieved this, if we put a stop to the greed that is spreading here, that we can ultimately successfully combat money laundering. And I wish you every success and good luck!

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The FinCEN files also have a surprisingly positive side effect, because at last everyone knows what the American FinCEN is. We urgently need an authority like the American FinCEN in Europe. Well, they may not have paid proper attention to their data now, but that has certainly had a positive effect on the global debate on money laundering and on our debate here in Europe. The American FinCEN is an analysis agency that investigates money laundering throughout america and worldwide. The reason why some of the dirtiest banks in Europe – ABLV in Latvia – or even the situation in Cyprus have come under pressure is not because the European Commission or European and national authorities have mixed up the situation there, but because FinCEN has repeatedly put its finger on the wound with rigid investigations and has also threatened America with sanctions, as in the case of Latvia and Cyprus. During all this, the Commission has largely stood idly by. The American FinCEN analyses the suspicionreports for the whole of America. There are not 51 states, FIU, and 51 money laundering supervisors, but there is a common actor. We visited it together, with a cross-party delegation. We expect such an authority, Commissioner, in your proposal. An authority that can actually intervene, an authority that analyses together. Unfortunately, that is not what your action plan says. There is a common supervision of money laundering, but there is no common FIUs, but you only want to help the national authorities to cooperate better. However, for the large cross-border cases, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, we need a common financial intelligence unit so that, like America, we can really investigate large-scale money laundering cases. Then I have a question for you: I think it is good that you have finally sent questionnaires to some EU Member States because of the poor implementation of the fight against money laundering – not because of the transfer. Please tell us publicly here: which Member States were these? Secondly, when will you finally open infringement proceedings against the Member States that have been notoriously breaking European money laundering law since 2007? That is the question you need to answer.

name: Jorge BUXADÉ VILLALBA
text: ECR Group. – Madam President, the mass leak of documents by the US agency FinCEN has revealed the criminal activities of senior officials of the Maduro Government, who have amassed real fortunes by exposing their country's resources and drug trafficking; funds which, as has happened in some countries, such as Spain, have ended up funding the activities of communist and mafia political parties, which have the sole objective of destroying the social order, even though Mr Borrell came yesterday to tell us that Maduro was Snow White. The participation of European banks in money laundering operations from these illicit activities is also of great concern. We cannot, ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, allow drug addicts, terrorists and all sorts of criminals to go around in front of our noses, either by using financial engineering with European banks, or by transferring their funds to tax havens, such as Gibraltar, an infamous colony from which money from illicit activities has been laundered for years.  Get down to earth: out there are millions of jobless Europeans, there are thousands of honest entrepreneurs and families suffering, and it is absolutely obscene that, instead of fighting open field against money laundering operations, drug trafficking and terrorism, we are allocating thousands of funds and demanding that taxes be raised and new European taxes created to finance the climate festival of large globalist multinationals. What Europeans expect of us is something else.

name: Manon AUBRY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, it is the story of big banks, big fortunes and tax havens who think they are above the law. This story is that of the financial scandal of FinCEN files and its 2,100 billion transactions all more shady than the other. Tax evasion, tax evasion, money laundering, it is a story that we know by heart, so it repeats itself, always with the same protagonists. This is the story of the Panama Papers, the Paradise Papers, the Swiss Leaks, the list is endless. What has been revealed by the tremendous work of investigative journalists is therefore not a mere drift. It is a perfectly oiled system, the culprits of which are precisely identified. The major international banks first, including HSBC, Deutsche Bank, Société Générale which organize questionable financial transfers with impunity. The tax havens then always the same, the Cayman Islands, Cyprus, Hong Kong, the Virgin Islands which welcome dirty money in complete opacity. And to deal with it, the european Union's finance ministers have found nothing better this week than to remove the Cayman Islands from the blacklist of tax havens. It is true that it is not as if the Cayman Islands have not been mentioned in all the financial scandals of recent years. And without any notorious tax havens, especially European ones like Ireland or Luxembourg, your pseudo-blacklist is above all a carte blanche to financial scheming. So how long will it take to endure the crocodile tears of the leaders who cry foul without ever giving themselves the means to put an end to it. Citizens are no longer able to afford this class tolerance for white-collar financial delinquency while being asked to pay the cost of the crisis. It's time to get the money where it is.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, organised crime, major evaders, terrorists, powerful men orbiting the political and economic world: these are the protagonists who move rivers of money and do business, exploiting the dark side of the world's financial system. According to the FinCEN files investigation, this would be done thanks to tax havens, offshore companies and the leading role played by the large complacent international banks, some of which operate in Europe. In the European Union, we have adopted the Sixth Anti-Money Laundering Directive. Money laundering cannot and must not become a form of profit for banks, especially if it exceeds the costs of possible sanctions; we cannot allow inaction in combating these criminal activities to end up fuelling economic inequality, distorting market rules and draining resources intended to finance services that are essential to citizens.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, Vice-Presidents, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The FinCEN papers are another example of the depth of the quagmire of money laundering, corruption and financial crime, and how huge the common need for action is. We can only win the fight against this money laundering, corruption and crime together – globally and europeanly. Around EUR 2 000 billion – or about five percent of world economic output – is laundered worldwide every year. But we in the European Union also have EUR 110 billion – that is very, very close to the EU's annual budget. The citizens are therefore right to ask themselves: how many more revelations will it take for us to finally turn the tap on the criminal networks? It's outrageous! There is still a contradiction between regulation, commitment and implementation. The fourth and fifth money laundering directives have still not been implemented. There is still a patchwork rug. And we still need more control, staff and sanctions, a single European procedure, a money laundering regulation instead of a directive, a common supervision of money laundering – perhaps even an authority – a European financial police force, a European reporting agency. Ladies and gentlemen, we are finally doing what we have been committed to for years throughout Europe.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Madam President, as Manon Aubry said, this is not the first time we have had LuxLeaks, Panama Papers, Paradise Papers, and I agree with Sven Giegold – transparency is a wonderful thing. But let’s face it, this story has been told a thousand times. We in this room know it; ordinary people are still confused by the tools that are used. They don’t usually have trusts in Jersey, a Swiss bank account or a shell company in the Netherlands, and they don’t get it. But we must realise – certainly the people that are aware – that this is used mainly by the rich: terrorists, criminals, the rich. They own the hidden wealth in the world, at least half of the hidden wealth according to calculations by economists, and it’s not even the one percent that owns the hidden wealth in offshore jurisdictions. It’s the one percent of the one percent that owns half of the hidden wealth in the world. It is very clear from the FinCEN files that action needs to be taken and not enough action has been taken so far. Because now bankers blindly forward transactions to their financial investigations unit (FIU), only to find out later that they have facilitated fraudulent transactions. And these FIUs on the other hand are flooded with information but lack the means and resources to keep up.  If transactions are investigated and found to breach law, the money has long been gone. Take former President Yanukovych, who was able to transport billions out of Ukraine, or take former president’s daughter Isabel Dos Santos, by now the richest woman in Africa. She is also spending her days in luxury, not in Angola but in Russia and other places.  So what we need is to staff and strengthen FIUs, and of course, FIUs need to exchange information on close cooperation, but in addition we need to make banks act upon their role as gate-keepers. Forwarding alone is not enough. Banks need to know their customers and when they find suspicious activities, press pause.  The point is, of course, that making private actors fulfil public roles is hard. It cannot be done without clear rules, strict oversight and very tough penalties. We need to work on that now so that we can avoid former dictators spending their days in luxury.

name: Gilles BOYER
text: Madam President, scandals like this regularly undermine the confidence of European citizens in our financial and tax system. We can react, that is what we are doing this morning, but above all we must act and respond to this feeling of unfairness, injustice and fiscal opacity at the global level and also, it must be said, sometimes within the European Union. And we will all be judged on what we will do or what we will not do, the Commission will be judged on this, the Council will be judged on this and we, Parliament, will also be judged on this.  We have recently given a strong political signal by creating a subcommittee specifically responsible for these issues in our Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. A commission that will be permanent, not temporary, to fight tax evasion and evasion and so that everyone, starting with the most powerful, pays what they owe, where they owe it.  And you can count on our vigilance for the implementation of the Commission's ambitious tax package. You can count on our vigilance to appeal to the public on issues that have been blocked in the Council for years, such as the common corporate tax base. And more generally, you can count on our determination to call on the Council to end the rule of unanimity in tax matters, which obviously is a blocking factor and prevents us from moving forward.

name: Jaak MADISON
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Van Rompuy, for his excellent work This is a very interesting topic. Firstly, I will introduce myself to the fact that I am quite well aware of this issue, as my home party in Estonia is in government and the chairman of our party is the Minister of Finance. And in Estonia between 2005 and 2014, there was very large-scale money laundering, which was then organised through a danish bank, a branch of Danske Bank in Estonia, Russia, basically to the Foundation and Western countries. However, I do not agree in any way with the solution that is being offered here. The European Commission, as well as a large part of the European Parliament, are calling for the creation of a new body, the creation of a new bureaucracy, more power, the reduction of the power of the Member States. However, I know very well the example of our country: in the last year, when we are in government, it is possible, with political will, to investigate criminal cases of money laundering. We have concluded very effective agreements, we have tightened criminal laws, we have placed new obligations on the banks, without the great assistance or political pressure of the European Commission and the European Parliament, so thank you for offering assistance in the fight against money laundering, but we politely refuse.

name: Saskia BRICMONT
text: Madam President, Commissioner, from 2013 with the Offshore Leaks, to 2020 with the FinCEN queues, through the LuxLeaks, SwissLeaks, Panama Papers, Paradise Papers, Dubai Papers, it is first and foremost the work of journalists and whistleblowers, who have made it possible to expose these criminal acts, that we owe this information and to which I would like to pay tribute today. Your revelations have fuelled the work of this Parliament for years so that the mafia, the oligarchs, the despots, the terrorists, the drug lords, but also the crooked politicians stop plundering collective resources with the complicity of unscrupulous banks, such as the Deutsche Bank or ING which are pointed in the FinCEN files. At a time when the funds are being scraped from drawers to respond to the consequences of the COVID crisis, how can we explain why 2 trillion suspicious financial transactions are possible through banks recapitalized with this public money?  FinCEN sounds like a wake-up call. To obstruct the actions of criminals and crooked politicians, banks must comply with their anti-money laundering obligations and the government must compel them to do so. What are our governments and the Council, which is once again conspicuous by its absence, to implement European legislation once and for all, to stop turning a blind eye to the support provided by banks to criminal enterprises and to apply heavy fines and criminal sanctions against bank executives, to encourage the establishment of the European Financial Supervisory Unit , to strengthen EU-wide investigative and prosecution capabilities, to strengthen financial crime services to effectively combat these financial crimes.  And let's not forget that behind these transactions, this crime, there are also thousands of victims. Victims of drug trafficking, corruption, terrorism and armed conflict. All these activities are made possible by a common denominator: the dirty money that circulates through the banks. Therefore, the rights of the victims must be guaranteed as well as their compensation.

name: Beata KEMPA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Thank you very much for your voice in this very important discussion in Europe, but also in the world. I am from Polish and I invite you Polish because very often here Poland is being lured for allegedly not respecting the rule of law, and it is in Poland that it is very effective in fighting white-collar criminals, especially those who brazenly exploit bank customers, including money laundering. There is practically no week, no month, so that the public does not find out about the further arrests and allegations made in these activities that we are discussing today. Here you have to be effective and put on a very effective fight, give tools to the prosecutor's office and demand that it work effectively. This is the case today under the direction of The Attorney-General of Justice, Mr Zbigniew Ziobra. Powerful bankers, firmly located at the height of power, who have extensive international connections and work for the largest European banks – this is the scandal. It is necessary to fight it, not to talk about combat, but to introduce with a hard hand legislation that will curb this brazen practice.

name: José GUSMÃO
text: – Madam President, the European Commission came here to cry crocodile tears in the same week that it removed the Cayman Islands from the list of non-cooperative offshores, such a short list that I would say that it would indicate that jurisdictions, at least in Europe, are all very cooperative with the authorities, that it becomes difficult to understand why these scandals continue to repeat themselves and the only ones who have done anything to combat money laundering have been journalists and the whistleblowers who have promoted these scandals. Because this scandal, in particular, has there the banks, many of them European, German, French, Cypriots, has there transactions, there are the crimes that have been promoted and of which these banks are accomplices.  What will happen to these European banks? What will happen to the Member States that are at the top of the world financial secrecy ranking and which protect these banks?  The Commission says it will not hesitate to hold Member States accountable. We have been hearing this conversation from the Commission for years and what we see is the Commission hesitating, hesitating, hesitating.

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, we in Croatia also have great problems with money laundering. Recently, the Zagrebacka Banka scandal and the laundering of large amounts of money were revealed, three board members resigned. The Central Bank, the Croatian National Bank, was supposed to protect it all, control it, but by the old custom it covered it all up and maybe participated in it. And what Croatian citizens and the whole of Europe have from these banking criminals, there is really nothing. While they launder billions, we have 100 million poor citizens in Europe.  Many of them are children. We have millions and millions of poor children, in Croatia we have more than 200,000 poor children. Children who are poor are stressed, undernourished, develop more slowly, learn less and have a great chance of being poor one day. We can end all this by getting the wealth of this continent off these unfortunate banks and give it to those who really need it. Let's give these people, give those kids a chance at life. This is not only an economic issue, this is both a moral and civilizational issue of this world in the 21st century.

name: David CASA
text: – Sinjura President, gsal darb'osra gsandna leak kbir ta' dokumenti b'rabta mal-aasil ta' flus u l-kriminalià organizzata. Il-FinCEN leaks huma differenti minn dawk tal-Panama Papers, jew Paradise Papers gsaliex dawn l-elfejn u 1ames mitt dokument ma jitkellmux biss dwar każijiet ta' flus li saru minn persuna jew kumpanija wasda. Anzi dawn id-dokumenti jagstu stampa ara ta' dak li qed jiri fid-dinja u ta' kemm din l-attività kriminali hi kbira, u and, bl-użu tal-banek.  ertu banek qed jagsmlu rapporti dwar affarijiet żgsar waqt li fl-istess 서in qed jippermettu l-aasil ta' flus tal-kriminalità organizzata. And mhux qed jiri biss fl-Istati Uniti, imma gsandna problema wkoll fl-Ewropa. Gsalhekk gsandna bżonn regoli ari li jindirizzaw dawn il-prattiki.  L-gsan tagsna mhux li nżidu l-ispejjeż gsall-banek jew li nagsmluha impossibbli g aal negozji onesti li jkomplu bil-서idma tagshom. L-gsan tagsna hu li nwaqqfu lill-kriminali milli jabbużaw mis-sistema finanzjarja b'detriment gsa-ittadini onesti. L-gsan tagsna gsandu jkun il-aasil tal-flus li jkun identifikat, jitwaqqaf u li dawk li jkunu involuti jiffajaw il-ustizzja.  And gsandu jsir billi jkollna, iva, FIUs iktar b'sa aithom u jkollna wkoll regolament fuq livell Ewropew against l-aasil tal-flus. Jiena nappella li and isir malajr kemm jista' jkun biex inwaqqfu lil dawn il-kriminali.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Madam President, a new debate on additional money laundering scandals. We've been on this road too long. What we all share is that we all want to end money laundering.  But it turns out that, so far, we regulate through directives, that States interpret, and that in many cases they do not apply. We have national supervisors who are unable to control, in a global capital market with full freedom of movement. And then we have lists of tax havens where there are states that come and go, anyway, without knowing very well what the requirements are to get the Cayman Islands or other countries off those lists. We need regulations, European regulation. We need a supervisor and a European Public Prosecutor's Office, and we need to take combat very seriously, the fight against tax havens where money laundering passes.

name: Ondřej KOVAŘÍK
text: – Madam President, the FinCEN files show clearly the sheer quantity of suspicious transactions taking place in US dollars across the globe, including the EU. It is no different if we consider transactions in euros or other currencies in the EU. This highlights the need for better global cooperation.  The FinCEN case also demonstrates that reporting works, because reports are filed in the first place. However, what happens after these are reported is what truly matters. Do the authorities adequately check and if necessary investigate activities? In the EU, Europol reported, for instance, that there were one million STRs in 2014. Of these only ten percent were further investigated and only one percent of the money reported as suspicious was recovered. This was not a one—off. This is indeed a trend, repeating itself since the early 2000s. So clearly we are missing a link. We need better supervision and information sharing, not just between national, European and international authorities, but also between banks and, importantly, within banking groups. I believe that one of these missing links could be a more generalised use of regulatory and supervisory technologies based, for instance, on AI for processing transactions. This could significantly improve compliance with regulations, identify suspicious activities faster and more efficiently, and also signal them to the relevant authorities. So, yes, let’s strengthen our regulatory framework, but let’s also beef up the authorities so that they are able to have an efficient fight against money laundering in Europe.

name: Peter KOFOD
text: Madam President! This is an incredibly important issue. Money laundering is pure fuel for other forms of serious crime, terrorism, gang crime, corruption and other organised crime. In other words, it is very, very important that urgent action is taken and that our countries become better at tackling the fight against money laundering.  I do not necessarily believe that it is just a question of more EU regulation. On the other hand, I believe that there is a need for better enforcement of the legislation that already exists; the different countries will be better at informing and helping each other, exchanging information, complementing each other's work. Whatever one has of great ambition, it is in the Member States that the muscles must solve this problem.  So let's ditch all the big bowl speeches and actually focus on the practical things that have already been legislated for, make it work and take action against crime.

name: Claude GRUFFAT
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, LuxLeaks, Panama Papers, FinCEN, scandal after scandal, it is clear that Europe and the States still find good reasons not to upset their big banks. Financial crime is a juicy business. This is all the more scandalous in the current economic context and in the looming crisis. Where has European political courage gone? Who was to protect taxpayers and the real economy from the excesses of finance? The FinCEN scandal proves the conscious involvement of the big European banks in money laundering. These unacceptable practices must not be left unheeded. How can we ask citizens for a code of conduct when big finance is allowed to act as a thug without sanctioning it? The FinCEN files must motivate and inspire an ambitious reform of the European financial system. It is time for the Commission to put in place rules that govern the practices of the big European banks. All illicit financial transactions that penalize our economies, our exemplarity and undermine the founding values must be punished. I ask you to impose real controls and deterrent sanctions to match the abuses. Let us no longer give banks the right to defraud as the carbon economy has been given the rights to pollute.

name: Nikolaj VILLUMSEN
text: Madam President! Major criminals, violent crime syndicates, drug cartels, arms smugglers, terrorists and corrupt oligarchs have infiltrated the financial system. I'm afraid this is nothing new. What's new is that the FinCEN files put names and flesh and blood on a small corner of the rot.  In Denmark, the revelations have hit the biggest bank of them all, Danske Bank. Decades of deregulation and starvation of control of banks and the financial sector have given criminals all too easy play. We need international action, a determined effort. We need tighter regulation of banks, we need better public control and a public society bank.  Ladies and gentlemen, when the EU removes the Cayman Islands from the list of tax havens, the EU not only stamps a notorious tax haven, it is helping to weaken efforts against rottenness and money laundering. It's not going to work. Money laundering and tax havens must and must be combated!

name: Pedro MARQUES
text: – Madam President, once again the scandal of illegal money transfers across the world to escape capital control, to escape sanctions, always with opacity and tax evasion as a backdrop. Europe must act, talk less and do more, finally move towards tougher regulation, but above all mandatory in all Member States and European control bodies with sufficient resources to act. Capitalknows no borders, and it is therefore clear that national states cannot be effective in their own way.  From Europe we do not need regulation like the one that led to this week's Council decision to remove the Cayman Islands from the list of tax havens. What we need, and that is, stronger sanctions on non-cooperative countries.  It is not permissible for the world to continue to be able to take advantage of opacity as a factor of competitiveness.  Let us make this a fight for all so that citizens do not continue to lose confidence in the institutions.

name: Nicola BEER
text: Before we continue the debate, I will open the first round of voting today. The dossiers on which we are now voting can be found on the agenda. The voting round is open from 9.30 a.m. to 10.45 a.m. The same voting procedure will apply as in the previous voting rounds. All votes are roll-call votes. I hereby declare the first round of voting open. You can now vote until 10.45 a.m. The results of the first round of voting will be announced at 12.30 p.m.

name: Nicola BEER
text: We are now continuing the debate on the Commission's statement on combating money laundering on the basis of the FinCEN files (2020/2812(RSP)."

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Madam President, first and foremost, two trillion US dollars – that’s what was exposed in the context of the recent FinCEN files. The fact of the matter is that it’s sophisticated, it’s complex and it’s massive, and it’s on a global scale. The idea that national supervisors alone, or regulators or enforcers, can deal with this particular challenge simply is delusional  From that context, we have to insist that we have closer cooperation, that we have proper international enforcement and that we do say what we need in terms of insisting that there are prosecutions. HSBC, JP Morgan, Barclays, Deutsche Bank, Standard Chartered, they’re not tinpot banks. They are massive banks that underpin the financial system across the globe, and yet they’re named in these files. We have oligarchs, we have drug dealers, we have terrorists, we have all forms of everything going through these banking systems, and yet nothing happens.  We have consistently, in this Chamber, highlighted this particular fact, but until such time as there is proper enforcement and, more importantly, underpinning of enforcement with resources, because these, as I said, are very sophisticated and complex, from that point of view, I think that the European Union, the United States and other countries have to come together on an international level to ensure that we can root out this. We can go to any capital in Europe and see quite clearly that there is dirty money washing around very close to the regulatory systems.

name: Maximilian KRAH
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I hear a great deal about new authorities, new regulations, new bans, but I also warn against losing proportionality in the fight against the one objective, namely money laundering. Deutsche Bank says it has invested one billion euros in new compliance institutions in response to the FinCEN files. I do not believe that they contribute to prosperity in Europe. Anyone who wants to open a new account with your commercial bank today as a medium-sized entrepreneur has to torment yourself with a medium thick pile of paper on forms. It simply goes so far that we now want new financial police, new reporting obligations. Do you really believe that they serve to eliminate the European Union's chronic growth weakness? In this respect, I can only warn against ever-reacting with new regulations, new bans and new authorities. We simply have to recognise that there are criminals, and we must not cause more damage by fighting these criminals than money laundering itself does.

name: Kira Marie PETER-HANSEN
text: – Madam President, I will continue this speech in Danish so that even Danske Bank can also hear me.  Madam President! It is a bit of fun to sit four Danish colleagues in here today, but it is perhaps no wonder, because between 2007 and 2015, 1 500 suspicious billion kroner flowed through Danske Bank's branch in Estonia without the banks discovering anything, and without the financial supervisory authorities talking properly and being able to address it. Last week we received a little more information about this when we saw with FinCEN that it was part of an organised network of criminal backers who use established banks like Danske Bank to launder huge sums of money. These are money linked to illicit arms trafficking, drug cartels and terrorism; and it is money that would have been much better spent on the climate law we adopted today, or on welfare in the Member States.  Now we are waiting so anxiously to hear what the Commission's anti-money laundering authority will look like. Needless to say, it will have to deliver and that it must be as strong as possible. The FinCEN files also showed that one-third of all activities flowed through the Cayman Islands and, as my colleague from the Unity List said, the Cayman Islands were nevertheless removed from the tax havens list. That's not good enough. This is as absurd as it sounds, and the EU Finance Minister will have to revise the list. In the Green Group, we will be pushing for a strong anti-money laundering authority and a strong tax haven list, and we look forward to cooperation.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: Madam President, then the financial scandals follow one another, with their procession of opaque transactions, of illegal immoral practices with astronomical sums unimaginable to ordinary people, and here we have a new example. And I wonder what society we live in when such practices are greeted with shrugs or resignation on the part of European leaders.  So obviously we have to say our anger because the finCEN files reveal criminal transactions since 1999. There were directives, which obviously were not acted upon. Especially since here we have banks that have a foothold on the street. Deutsche Bank 62% of fraudulent transactions, out of 2000 billion. HSBC, which had made promises on anti-money laundering, is wet up to its neck. So we must not just be outraged, but we must also act, by turning anti-money laundering directives into regulations. Because we can see that there is a failure of the national regulators. Sanctions must be taken against the culprits. I think it is necessary, as the European Parliament requested in 2019, to place a European regulator with real human resources above national regulators.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Another new financial scandal. So slowly we lose track. In order for us to finally put an end to this whole money laundering financial tax scandal, despite the wave of liberalisation, we need two things: centralised strong controls and strong uniform regulations. The fact that money laundering transactions can take place at all is partly due to the fact that the banks themselves decide which money transfers they consider suspicious and which do not. In fact, banks do not even have to stop the transfers they themselves consider suspicious. The FinCEN files have also shown that the suspicions are often made so late that the law enforcement authorities cannot really do anything, because 166 days was the average. 166 days - the money is already gone. That is why we need strong supervisory authorities, preferably a European FBI, well-trained staff in the national banks themselves and harmonisation of national anti-money laundering laws.

name: Luis GARICANO
text: – Madam President, again one more scandal, again I have to hear my colleagues on both sides of the aisle complaining, and again we see that nothing happens in the fight against money laundering.  I think that the key to the answer is that Europe needs to be more confident in this fight. We have shown that we can be regulatory leaders. We have put the GDPR standard, and some people would have been afraid that, with this standard, Facebook or some others would not operate in Europe. The fact of the matter is that, whatever the threats, they cannot afford not to operate in Europe.  This is similar. If we say to world companies, to companies based abroad, you can’t operate here unless we know who is your owner, if we rule out beneficial ownership, it is not going to be the case that people are going to renounce a 400 million market. They are going to want to be here, they are going to want to serve European citizens. So if we are confident and we set out the regulatory standards for transparency, for disclosure, for this beneficial ownership, it is going to be the case that companies will have to comply.  What are the main things we need to change in the way this fight is going? I think we need three things. We need transparency, as I was saying, particularly no opaque companies – we need to know who is behind every account. We need a European financial intelligence unit – we need to know what is going on, and that requires police work. And we need a single supervisory authority that is able to centralise and doesn’t succumb to the economic nationalism that we are always seeing, with each authority protecting their own banks and their own transactions, and each authority happy to receive money from abroad.  So this is the moment to show that Europe is confident. I have heard all my colleagues speak and I have taken close note. I think that we all see things in a very similar way. We need to really change the way we are doing things. We need a confident Europe that leads in this fight.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Madam President, we are again facing a major scandal –EUR 2 trillion that has gone in money laundering and the big institutions like Deutsche Bank are really affected. But what strikes me is that OK, we have the information, it’s a new investigation – for which we have to thank the journalists – but now we need to act and here is where we really meet a problem at the European level: we have to do much more. There are three things to mention to the Commissioner that I think are extremely urgent: Firstly, as many of my colleagues have said before, we need these intelligence units to fight money laundering and to fight financial crime. It’s not in the action plan, but we need it and I think that this Parliament is united behind that idea. Secondly, as Mr Sven Giegold has mentioned before, when we have a serious problem at Member State level of enforcing our framework against money laundering, we need infringement procedures, and it would be good, Commissioner, for you to tell us when you will start doing that.  Finally, and I will end here, I think it is a real shame that the Council has taken the Cayman Islands out of the tax haven list this week. This is something that our citizens cannot understand.

name: Franco ROBERTI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the FinCEN files once again show the failure of the anti-money laundering rules in the face of the pro-money-laundering conduct of banks and financial operators, which continue to profit from crime. European anti-money laundering legislation is not being sufficiently implemented in too many EU countries. We certainly need a uniform system, we certainly need a European anti-money laundering agency, as the Commission also pointed out since the last parliamentary term, but above all, if money laundering is the essence of organised crime, we need a unified European strategy aimed at the disarticulation of transnational criminal organisations and their external accomplices, through full investigative and judicial cooperation. To this end, I had called, unnecessarily so far in the total indifference of all the political groups, for the establishment of a special European Parliament committee against organised crime, terrorism and corruption, which are increasingly intertwined, which are a growing threat to the rule of law in the countries of the Union. After the establishment of five special committees, I hope that in the near future the political will to give priority to this issue will mature if we are to defend the rule of law and the real economy against the onslaught of criminal powers.

name: Henrike HAHN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has With the FinCEN files, we can see how flawed and flawed our system is when it comes to countering money laundering. We see revelations about the criminal activities of internationally operating banks that are involved in money laundering – with the mafia, with terrorist operatives, with drug bosses – and in the midst of this process are Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank. Criminals take advantage of the fact that state oversight – which was actually created per se to avert such scandals – does not work. Banks do not seem to have a problem with their behaviour even after the financial crisis, and policies are becoming meaningless because of the many loopholes. That is why we need a clear 'yes' from the EU Member States to a central European authority against money laundering – a clear 'yes' that must happen now and not last for many years. And we need a clear 'yes' to the implementation of existing rules with a legal framework that is harmoniously implemented in the EU, without outliers who would rather wait for and risk infringement proceedings than do something. Only joint, better coordination in Europe can make a difference to this unethical feeling – and we must do something about it now.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I thank the honourable Members for all their comments and I definitely take note of all they have said. What I heard today confirms the Commission’s resolve to act swiftly and address the shortcomings of the Union’s anti-money laundering legal framework. There were some questions which I would like to answer, especially from Mr Giegold and Mr Urtasun. You were asking about cases where we have sent formal letters to Member States, and these are publically known. The Commission has opened infringement procedures against Member States that failed to notify transposition of the 5th Anti-Money Laundering Directive against Cyprus, Hungary, Netherlands, Portugal, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia and Spain.  In parallel, we are continuing to check those Member States that have fully and correctly transposed the 4th Anti-Money Laundering Directive. I cannot disclose here to which Member States we have sent informal letters. However, rest assured, that over the course of the next years, we will address all Member States. Let me stress again, the enforcement and effective implementation of the existing rules remain a top priority for the Commission. We are also stepping up practical work to help national authorities detect money laundering. For example, the interconnection of beneficial ownership – ownership registers – should be operational in 2021. A similar interconnection between bank account registers is also part of our action plan, as it will speed up cross—border access to bank account information. However, criminals are highly adaptive and their methods are constantly evolving. The FinCEN revelations clearly illustrate the ongoing challenges that the main actors face in their efforts to detect illegal financial flows and prevent criminals from using the financial system to launder dirty money. Our framework must therefore continuously evolve in order to keep pace with technological developments and the growing sophistication of financial crime.  We are up to the challenge. In the first quarter of 2021, we will propose an ambitious anti-money laundering package in order to further strengthen the capacity to fight money laundering and protect the integrity of the financial system. In a single market, we can no longer afford to work in silos. We need to build bridges between anti-money laundering supervisors and financial intelligence units. For this, we need not only a stronger regulatory framework but also strong European Union level structures to ensure its implementation. I wanted to be fair to those who mentioned the Cayman Islands. I wanted to clarify. There are two lists: one list is anti-money laundering and the other is fiscal cooperation tax. So some Members were mixing this up, but okay. Some Members were speaking about tax non-cooperative jurisdiction, but of course we have to deal with this too. Thank you for this debate. The Commission and my colleague Valdis Dombrovskis, who was not able to attend this meeting today, we look forward to continuing to work with you on these crucial issues in order to further strengthen the integrity of the financial system and to ensure that dirty money finds no place to hide in the European Union. Thank you once again for this fruitful debate.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: – Madam President, I have to say I am appalled by that response and I ask you, President, to hold the Commission... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Nicola BEER
text: Mr Giegold, I would like to thank Mr Giegold for his A point of order, gladly, otherwise we cannot have the debate here ... Yes, then you give reasons for the point of order, but do not make a statement!

name: Nicola BEER
text: I think the Commission heard the question and will find a way to respond to that, but not now here in a public debate. I’m sorry. This was not really something on the agenda.

name: Nicola BEER
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. The publication of the FinCEN files, which reveal reports of suspicious activity also coming from European banks to the US anti-money laundering agency, totalling EUR 2 099 billion over the period 2000-2017, demonstrate, despite the rules adopted, once again the legislative loopholes of the European legal system in the fight against money laundering and the ease with which the illicit profits made by criminal organisations are laundered in Europe and around the world. At the July plenary session, we welcomed the Commission communication on an action plan to update the fourth and fifth anti-money laundering directives. I would like to stress strongly the need and urgency to establish a single body of legislation at Community level, including by transponing the provisions of the anti-money laundering directive into a regulation; create a European AML/CFT supervisory authority and a support and coordination mechanism for FIUs; ensure effective cooperation and exchange of information between them and law enforcement authorities. Stricter rules on suspicious money movements, greater transparency on the part of all financial operators and coordinated investigative activity between Member States can stop money laundering by criminal organisations by ensuring security for citizens and healthy competition between companies.

name: Nicolás GONZÁLEZ CASARES
text: in writing. – The FinCEN archives scandal revealed by an investigation by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists once again showed that there are many gaps in European legislation and supervision in the fight against money laundering.  The S&D Group has long been at the forefront of driving a European framework in the fight against money laundering and the financing of terrorism. FinCen revelations come to give reason to our demands. We are now asking, more than ever, that existing legislation go beyond that which is clearly insufficient to prevent and combat criminal activity which is increasingly complex and cross-border.  We therefore support the shift to EU legislation setting standards that exceed the current minimums to ensure a more prescriptive set of rules, which is effectively implemented by Member States and that prevents and penalizes the bad behaviour of financial institutions.

name: Lídia PEREIRA
text: in writing. – Combating money laundering must be a priority of the European Union. The successive scandals and revelations, to which the FinCEN files are added, are proof that Member States are not in themselves able to eradicate this crime which, in addition to corruption, is at the root of the financing of criminal and terrorist organisations. Among the various institutions cited are European banks that have moved billions with suspicious backgrounds over 17 years.   We therefore need greater European integration in this area. In the immediate end, we need the Member States to transpose and, above all, implement, urgently and correctly, the European Money Laundering Directives, especially the fourth and fifth.  The May Commission communication on the matter must be consistent and this Parliament must be ready to respond with ambition. In the face of evidence of criminal activity, banking institutions cannot consent to the continuity of financial transactions. We must move forward with binding rules in the field of regulation. I therefore call on the Commission to submit a proposal for a Regulation to that effect. In the long term we also need to discuss the establishment of a European supervisory authority and coordination of national structures to combat this crime.

name: Nicola BEER
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on long-term care facilities (2020/2794(RSP)).

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, what we are discussing here today is people’s lives. Talking about long—term care facilities means talking about both those giving and receiving care in a particularly vulnerable situation. Due to protective measures, persons in care could no longer receive family and visitors. Long—term care facilities could not immediately provide the type of care required in such exceptional circumstances.  At particular moments in life we also rely on the commitment and dedication of others. Never has this been more visible than during the current pandemic, when carers held the hands of their residents. The staff in long—term care facilities did their best to provide not just comfort and dignity at the end of a precious life, but also a sense of tenderness and care.  People working in long—term care facilities deserve more than our applause and gratitude. We can pay tribute to them, but we must also take action. We need to deliver for residents and carers in our policymaking.  COVID—19 brings unprecedented challenges health—wise, economically and socially. Some people are more at risk than others, especially the elderly, and people with a disability. When it comes to social services, there are users and service providers; we cannot help one if we do not help the other. We have seen how care workers and those receiving care are particularly exposed to the virus and its devastating consequences. This is of great concern to us. We need to improve the protection of the most vulnerable in our societies. Too many lives have already been lost. We know that social services have been under particular strain and the Commission is committed to help. Together with Commissioners Nicolas Schmit, who is responsible for jobs and social rights, and Stella Kyriakides, in charge of health, and Helena Dalli, responsible for equality, we have held discussions with organisations focusing on services to the elderly, people with disabilities, and others who are in need of long—term care. We are listening to the sector and are assessing different instruments and possible solutions to support both providers and users of these services.  Not all of today’s problems are new. The capacity of long—term care facilities to deal with any crisis was laid bare by COVID—19. Clearly, there are structural deficiencies – the lack of staff, difficult working conditions, low salaries and access to services.  Ongoing issues with affordability and the quality of long—term care services also come to mind, as well as the availability of such services in rural and remote regions. This explains why we are assessing whether our social protection systems are fit to deal with the needs of an aging population. Families of women provide a large part of informal long—term care. Informal carers deserve better support such as social protection, income replacement, training, counselling and day care.  The gender care gap must be addressed, including the equal sharing of informal care responsibilities. We can do this through the implementation of the Directive on Work-life Balance, which should be transposed by 2022. Long—term care systems need revamping to better prepare them for rising long—term care needs and future health crisis. Funding issues must be addressed at Member State level because this is where the competence lies. However, I cannot stand here as a Member of the Commission and say that our hands are tied. We have been very active. I will share some examples with you.  The React—EU programme will continue and extend to the crisis response and repair measures by reinforcing capacities in health and long—term care. In addition, the Commission is working with the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control to protect vulnerable groups including older people in residential homes, but also in places like migrant centres and prisons.  The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control has published guidance on infection prevention, control and preparedness for COVID—19 in healthcare settings as well as guidance regarding surveillance of COVID—19 in long—term care facilities.  This guidance is a much needed tool for use right across the European Union. The joint report of the Commission and the Social Protection Committee on the preparedness of long—term care systems in the European Union will provide evidence and clear mapping of the challenges that need to be tackled. The Commission is committed to implementing the European pillar of social rights, including principles of access to quality health and long—term care. Preparations are ongoing for the upcoming action plan for the implementation of the European pillar of social rights to be adopted in 2021 under the guidance of my colleague Commissioner Schmit. The elderly must fully enjoy these rights, too. It is beyond doubt that COVID—19 has hit the elderly hardest. At the same time, our work in tackling demographic change shows that our Union is aging. Given the current and future context, we need to discuss this and factor it into all aspects of our policy action.  Let me be clear, dear Members of Parliament: aging concerns all generations, not just the elderly. In early 2021 we will present a Green Paper on aging with the aim of launching a wide debate to discuss the long—term impacts of aging, care and pensions, active aging and the capacity of social protection systems to deal with an aging population. We will look at inter—generational solidarity and fairness, impacts on the labour market, the economy, and health and care systems. A substantial part will deal with questions on long—term care. Based on the outcome of the consultations, the Commission could be in a better position to consider what further initiatives could be taken on long—term care. To conclude, dear ladies and gentlemen, to borrow a thought from Dostoevsky: you can best judge a society by how by how it treats its most vulnerable members, and those who take care of them. If we learn one lesson from the COVID—19 pandemic, let it be the importance of solidarity. Solidarity between generations must be one of the driving forces of Europe’s recovery, as set out in the Commission’s proposal for a major recovery plan to repair and prepare for the next generation. Only together can we successfully exit the crisis and build a future.  As I said at the beginning, we can pay tribute to the service providers, but we must also take action. We need to deliver for the service providers and users in our policymaking. In this I count on your support.

name: Cindy FRANSSEN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, thank you for your passionate speech. At the onset of corona pandemic, no one could have predicted the terrible tsunami that claimed so many lives. Our elders in particular were in the eye of the storm. The difficult choices in some hotly contested areas about who could be hospitalized and who could not, often resulted in an age-based decision. Choices that we as a society have not had to make since the Second World War. And let it be just that generation that has toiled to build our welfare state, just that generation we as a society have been physically and mentally deficient. However, the right to long-term care is contained in our social pillar.  Let's face it, at the first wave we were not prepared enough to deal with such a crisis. It is not the time to organise public tribunals on who bears ultimate responsibility. But above all, let's learn lessons.  We need to find a better balance between well-being and physical health, between the safety and mental well-being of our most vulnerable.  We must no longer surrender to visitation rights and the right to say goodbye with dignity.  And nest heat is the best medicine against the frailty and vulnerability of people with dementia.  The same conclusions can also be drawn for the disabled sector, for young people residing in a youth institution, and also for single elderly people receiving home care.  During our lack of action, the care staff have given the best of themselves. They have taken the human dramas on their already overloaded shoulders. A sector that has been sitting on its gums for years, undervalued and is not known to be the first to pass through the compensation box office.  That is precisely why, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome the initiative of my colleagues Fitzgerald and Radtke for their 'EU Carers' Strategy', in which they advocate better working conditions and better framework so that we can offer more quality of care. Our heroes of care deserve more than just a round of applause. Let the echo of that applause now resonate loudly in concrete actions!

name: Pierfrancesco MAJORINO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have seen a tragedy unfold in the tragedy that we cannot afford to ignore again, and that is why today's debate is important. In fact, more than half of covid deaths occurred in long-term care facilities, nursing homes, residences for the elderly and people with disabilities; Citizens who have often been shamefully left alone and who have dealt with workers and workers too often lacking personal protective equipment and training and safety protocols. This has happened in several countries of the European Union: I am also thinking, of course, of my own region, Lombardy, where a real black page has been written, with the failure of the social and health system and a shocking load of deaths, precisely in residences for the elderly and also as a result of the unfortunate choices of those who manage welfare. It is essential that the European institutions shed full light on what has happened, not only in order to identify obvious distortions and political responsibilities, which it is right and sacrosanct to identify, but also to avoid seeing the same tragic script repeated in recent months.  That is also why we need a more social Europe. The Commission must believe even more: more attentive to the right to health and care. We need more investment, new choices to deal with this second emergency phase without making the enormous mistakes of the past and, finally, we need to think about how to redesign the services themselves in the future. We must do this by involving the best and most significant third sector players, trade unions and citizens' associations. Europe is also the people who live in old people's homes and residences for the disabled: they deserve more community spirit and social ties and less carelessness.

name: Dragoș PÎSLARU
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, Commissioner Šuica, in the sad story of Covid-19, the situation of care institutions is one of the most disastrous chapters. A large part of the Member States of the Union - we must admit - have been wrong, and I hope that we can have, at some point, an investigation showing us what really happened and why these centres have become and continue to be outbreaks of infection. We are talking about the most vulnerable of European citizens, people in need of permanent care, people with disabilities or elderly people who have actually been abandoned in the face of the pandemic. In the absence of any contingency plan, the care staff have made extraordinary efforts and I would like to thank, on this occasion, all those who have remained on duty in the face of danger. Unfortunately, however, the mortality rate was extremely high. The Commission must work with Member States to find solutions in two directions: well-paid and trained care staff and modern centres where vulnerable people can receive the care they need safely. Renew Europe, our political group, is campaigning for a rethink of care and care centres in the management of communities to ensure that we no longer have situations of abandonment of vulnerable people in institutionalised systems. In the coming period, we must invest substantially in creating access and opportunity so that any European citizen who needs to be able to receive care in a sustainable way through direct access or within the community to which he is a member, without being excluded socially.  Last but not least, a modern care industry at European level can benefit both those who would enjoy its services, but also through job creation and the beneficial social impact it would have. A clear strategy on care at European level is, Commissioner, imperative.

name: Guido REIL
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which COVID-19 scares us. This is no wonder, because we get up with COVID-19 and go to sleep with COVID-19. I fear that the measures we are taking to combat the pandemic will do much more damage than the pandemic itself. I am not referring to the devastating economic consequences of these measures. No, I am referring to the measures that have been taken that affect the most vulnerable in society – people in care facilities. In Germany, one in two people who died of COVID-19 died in a nursing home. What measures has the government taken? It has isolated these people. She has imposed a ban on contact with their relatives. This measure did not save any lives – quite the contrary. It was incredibly cruel, it was inhumane, and it cost lives. Especially in such a difficult phase, these people naturally need the love and affection and the closeness to their loved ones. This would, of course, have been possible without any problems, while respecting the measures. We know that today. This must not happen again. This measure was cruel and inhumane. What happened to the secret heroes of the pandemic, our nurses, who were really on the front line, who sacrificed themselves? What did they get? Applause. And, otherwise? Applause is beautiful, appreciation. But was that all? Our federal government has provided ridiculous one-off payments – really ridiculous. But has anything changed in the basic situation of the nurses? Even before that, the situation was a disaster. A qualified nurse in Germany earns 2,500 euros gross. 2 500 Euros! To do so, she has to work eight hours hard, physically and emotionally. After these eight hours, she can usually sit down for one or two hours for documentation. I know this now, not because I have read this, but my wife is working there, so I know the problems. We finally need a policy of humanity.

name: Tilly METZ
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, it is unbearable that during this crisis the most vulnerable citizens, whether by their age or by their specific needs, suffered more than others during this crisis. This is in complete silence, with no adequate response from either member states or the European Union. Yet WHO sounded the alarm already in March about the dramatic situation in long-term care institutions in the EU, pointing out that half of the deaths related to COVID-19 had occurred in these institutions. Isolation, lack of equipment, protections and medicines, and lack of testing for residents have made these institutions nests of infection where health security measures have not been guaranteed. Many states have not even taken into account the people who died in these residences in their statistical accounts, wishing to hide the reality of the situation. I call on this Parliament to set up a commission of inquiry to shed light on what happened. Undignified treatment and human rights violations cannot remain without consequences. And it is our responsibility to give a voice to these people and to show that there are no second-class citizens in Europe. I will end with two questions to the Commission: do you agree that there is an urgent need to implement Article 19 of the Convention on the Law of Persons with Disabilities in Europe? And in doing so, to direct European investments towards care based on mutual aid, self-determination and life outside the specialized institutions, care that makes it possible to better respect the freedom of these people?

name: Elżbieta RAFALSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In a pandemic that continues and takes a deadly toll, the most dramatic situation has been the elderly in long-term care facilities. The elderly have been chronically ill and are most at risk of infection, and have a more severe course of the disease and higher mortality.
