The death rate among the elderly reaches 15%, and in nursing homes it is much higher. This was the case in many European countries – France, Spain, Belgium, Italy, where mortality was much higher, between 30% and even 50%. These facilities have become outbreaks of infections, which have also decimated staff, causing severe, difficult-to-fill staff shortages. Patients may have felt discriminated against.  The most drastic example is Spain, where selection was introduced when selecting patients for treatment. People in long-term care often did not go through the "sieve of life". It is shocking and unacceptable that in a Europe that speaks of solidarity, it wants to be in solidarity, such situations happen, and the dilemma of who to treat and who not to be treated must be decided by the doctor. We have an increase in Covid-19 cases and a seasonal increase in flu cases. How will these previous experiences affect the approach to long-term care? Will science be learned from this spring painful lesson? Little time, and we know more.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: for the GUE/NGL group. – Mr President, Commissioner, thousands of residents of these establishments, nursing homes, have died directly from COVID-19, but thousands more have died because of the isolation, fear and loneliness itself, which has worsened their condition, and we must not forget that. These people could live peacefully for the next 20 years and enrich younger generations with their knowledge and presence. I must say that I am a little appalled, Commissioner, when I hear you telling us that you will be creating new action plans and strategies. The care home system, the care of the elderly have been completely neglected here for 20 years. It is also underfunded by the Commission, which has decided several times to privatise or cut it. I expected you to take the money you're unnecessarily investing in armaments and like that to fund people who work in nursing homes and donate it to build new nursing homes. Action plans, strategies and talk will no longer help us. The staff and the people in these houses are the ones we need to be particularly interested in at the moment.

name: Antoni COMÍN I OLIVERES
text: – Mr President, we have known for years that one of the biggest challenges, but the greatest challenge of our health systems, is the ageing population. So far focused on acute diseases, these care models are increasingly focusing on the attention of chronicity. Our hope? To respond to this challenge from the community paradigm, which is to treat and care for the chronic patient without separating him from his own social and family environment. But let's not kid ourselves, because this virus has come to complicate things very dramatically. In order to protect the elderly population from the pandemic, health authorities have been obliged to issue drastic measures of isolation or, at the very least, restriction of the degree of social interaction of these older persons, both in residences and in homes, whether assisted or ordinary. What a contradiction! And in addition, professionals in long-term care facilities have often found thee very lonely in their fight against COVID, and very unprotected. It is imperative to provide them with more means and better working conditions, but above all, let us not wait until tomorrow to make a critical review of a model of residences that is far from a profound idea of intergenerational solidarity.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support More than anything, the epidemic has shown that those cared for in institutions are in a very vulnerable situation. Especially in nursing homes, there were many deaths in the spring. From this point of view, the case of the Hungarian capital, Budapest, was also very instructive. The left-wing city government, for political reasons, did not implement the defensive measures of the right-wing government. The aftermath was a tragedy. One home had 313 cared for workers and 21 workers infected, 55 of which died. Based on the investigations carried out, the responsibility is clearly the left-wing city administration. Dear Colleagues, the coronavirus is not politicized! We have to be united. Regardless of party aloe, I call on all my fellow politicians to unreservedly assist national governments in the fight against the epidemic. Even if they don't agree with that, at least don't obstruct them. Although we are already in the midst of the second wave, there is also a threat to the elderly or even those with disabilities, but it is still not too late to unite. Human lives cannot be sacrificed on the altar of politics!

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: – Mr President! I welcome today's debate, and I regret the fact that we are months late with it. This is confirmed by the WORLD Health Organisation data, as in the first wave of pandemics, more than half of the EU's deaths were elderly and other social institutions. This statistic is horrific and should never have happened. Unfortunately, there is no political will in the Member States or at EU level for a thorough investigation of the causes and correction of errors. The last few months have so entrenched the entrenched ness of old-fashioned or old-fashioned old-fashioned. As the EU population ages, ageing is a topic that has been avoided, approached by many prejudices and stereotypes, or equated with disease and ineading. This results in a huge number of socially excluded older people. We see them as a social burden, and we do not see home for the elderly as a warm home, but only as the last stop of life. However, human rights, including adequate medical care, belong to all people, at all ages and without any discrimination. It is intolerable that in the first wave of nursing homes and other institutions, many places across Europe have been left to their own devices and forced to become improvised hospitals, without adequate equipment and qualified medical staff. I therefore very much support the commitment of the President of the Commission to create a strong health union, but that is not enough. Together, we must also do more for solidarity between generations, the fight against age-based discrimination and full respect for the rights of the elderly. We urgently need a common European framework for long-term care based on human rights and social solidarity. I call on the Commission to establish a common framework of rules and standards for the quality of long-term care services, which will bind all members. It must be based on people's integrated needs and, in addition to nursing, provide social and psychological support for a period of life that, with the right approach of society and politics, can be as beautiful, learning and quality as any other.

name: Véronique TRILLET-LENOIR
text: Mr President, patient quality and safety must always be our priority. Residents of long-term care facilities, particularly in hospitals for the dependent elderly, have been particularly, for the most part, affected by the COVID-19 epidemic, which have been affected by the disease and are affected by the isolation of confinement. We must learn from this crisis and take the necessary steps: to strengthen supervision and preparedness of institutions. This is yet another example of the need for a Europe of health and the strengthening of the European Centre for Disease Control. We need to review the organization and structuring of these long-term care facilities. That is what the Member States are leaving. Finally, we need to improve the training and working conditions of staff, in conjunction with Commissioner Schmit. Not to mention the caregivers, both professional and family, who work tirelessly on a daily basis to accompany the most vulnerable, especially our elders. Thank you for initiating this necessary debate, it is not just a question of health, it is a question of human dignity.

name: Hélène LAPORTE
text: Mr President, patients in long-term care facilities have paid a heavy price for the pandemic, the number of deaths of which is also due to the drastic isolation imposed on these vulnerable people. Attached to a hospital, these units treat highly dependent people whose cognitive or behavioural abilities are impaired, whose condition requires constant medical supervision. COVID-19 has only increased the fragility of these patients, who are often suffering from progressive cancer, unstabilized heart or respiratory diseases, and Alzheimer's disease. According to the European social network, COVID-19 has disproportionately affected the elderly and has had a significant impact on the provision of long-term care. According to the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, between 30 and 60% of all deaths due to COVID-19 were verified in these facilities during the first months of the pandemic. Public authorities have faced many challenges in order to continue to provide long-term care, while addressing the lack of protective equipment available to health care workers. Social distancing and isolation have had a negative impact on the health and well-being of residents. Social life has been turned upside down by the installation of in camera, depriving the sick of their loved ones. The only connection with the outside world was through the nurses, whose masks did not allow for any facial expression. The protocol for authorized visits of relatives implies a physical distance of at least 1.5 meters excluding as such, any carnal link. Since the beginning of the pandemic, the general principle remains that of deferring new non-urgent admissions, thus excluding thousands of people from the benefit of such care, but we cannot continue in this way. Now is the time for solutions: the development of spaces for patients in isolation and visitors, as well as better cooperation between social and health authorities are necessary measures in each unit of care. The hypothesis of such a deadly second wave cannot be solved by a video of Mrs von der Leyen, teaching us to wash our hands. The current health situation means a complete rethinking of the provision of long-term care in Europe in order to better prepare for a new crisis.

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: – Mr President, no access to healthcare services, no infection protection measures or testing, isolation from society – but we did not only leave the residents of long—term care facilities without the necessary support, we forgot that elderly people and people with disabilities have the right to live independently and be included in the community. That is their fundamental human right. The right to independent life is not only our moral obligation, but also – above all – a matter of compliance with the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities that was ratified not only by all Member States, but also by the EU. We need to stop delaying the transition away from institutions now.

name: Lucia ĎURIŠ NICHOLSONOVÁ
text: – Mr President, firstly, we lack comparable data within the Member States of the European Union. Of those countries that keep such statistics, we learn terrible figures, 30 to 66% of all COVID deaths have occurred directly in social service facilities. According to the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, we lacked monitoring systems in social services facilities before the pandemic that could systematically monitor, for example, respiratory diseases in facilities and report in a timely manner at national level, thus preventing deaths. People with neurological conditions such as dementia or neuropathic disorders are particularly vulnerable. They show that they have absent symptoms until the patient's condition deteriorates rapidly, and it is often too late. This means that we must also start systematically monitoring this in social service facilities. The problem is the huge staffing under-pressure, which has already been said several times, and the lack of qualified staff in the labour market. They are not only lousyly paid people in some Member States, but also very vulnerable, they cannot maintain social distancing and often suffer from a lack of protective equipment. On the other hand, in Slovakia, and I would like to draw my attention to this, we have been shown cases in social service facilities where clients have been abused by staff, tethered to their beds or locked in rooms and restricted their movement. Of course, there were no visitors, relatives, so all of this was hidden. We clearly need to learn from this pandemic, set up monitoring systems, fill in the lack of qualified employees, collect comparable data, and effectively protect employees as well as clients.

name: Anne-Sophie PELLETIER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, people with disabilities, such as Dimitri Fargette, a young autistic person locked up in psychiatry, who has been locked up in psychiatry, elderly people in retirement homes, isolated, dead, bereaved families, infected carers, dead, such as Dr. Loupiac, for lack of protection, is the impact of COVID on long-term health care. We are told that health is not a competence of the Union but, under pressure from the Commission, it has become a variable for adjusting national budgets. Accounting logics, which attack the number of beds, carers, hospitals in a territory are responsible for unpreparedness, chaos and death. Contrary to the Commission's recommendations, the dysfunctions of national systems do not stem from a mismatch between supply and demand, which makes no sense when it comes to health, but from a disrepute, from organised abuse, which coordinated the dismantling and privatisation of our public health services. Colleagues, we measure the state of health of a society in its care of its sick, injured and injured in life.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, the unacceptable situation in nursing homes and long-term care institutions throughout the European Union is not only about the period of corovirus, but reflects the barbarity that prevailed earlier. The EU policy implemented in Greece by New Democracy and SYRIZA, as well as in health care, was that of deliberately minimal and degraded, underfunded and understaffed public structures, to pave the way for the over-benefits of private welfare groups. The result is the mistreatment of the elderly and the units that are outbreaks of virus infection, both for the elderly and for workers.  You are only interested because the outbreaks of nursing homes fill the minimum ICU beds of commercialised public health systems with intubated beds. Criterion is cost-benefit for you and individual liability with disclaimer for private groups. So today there is an urgent need to strengthen the precautionary measures, the mass repeated tests, the immediate permanent recruitment of staff, the requisition of private units and the assumption of responsibility for them by the State, as well as their inclusion in the state plan with free services.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Millions of elderly, terminally ill, immunocompromised people are in long-term care facilities. 86% of the staff at these centres are women – nurses, medical caregivers – often employed for financial reasons in several different institutions or hospitals, which increases the risk of transmission of the virus. The staff of these centres signal the lack of adequate personnel and equipment protection, which leads to a high mortality rate there. Additional isolation and lack of contact with loved ones do not facilitate treatment.  It should also be borne in mind that if increased restrictions are introduced, many carers may not get to work, others will take leave or dismissal because they have no one to take care of their families or their children.  We must be aware that without adequate hardware, human resources and financial support, without better remuneration of staff, the situation in these establishments will not be improved, because it is difficult to fight the epidemic when basic protection equipment is lacking: masks, gloves or overalls.  One colleague said that in Germany the salary of such employees is 2.5 thousand euros. I ask you, in eastern European countries, such a worker earns only a few hundred euros – this is embarrassingly low in view of the commitment and threat. Commissioner, action and response are needed here and now, not in 2021. I know that this is the responsibility of the Member States, but in many of these countries, without the support of the Commission, it will only get worse.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, whether you lost your job, your health was in trouble or your loved ones had to miss out, we all have our own story about how corona has affected our lives, and still does. But iCu's, homes and nursing homes all over Europe have been particularly hard hit and in many places they have had to be hermetically locked. No one got in anymore.  My own sister lives in a residential care complex and was not allowed to receive a visit for months – just a phone call or waving from the parking lot, that's all it took. Many families in Europe have been through the same thing and for months were not allowed to see and cuddle their grandparents, their father, their mother, their sister, their brother, and any kind of humanity was lost.  Unfortunately, everything at the moment points to that so-called – hated – second wave. Please let Europe take the lead now and tackle this crisis together, because it is up to the Commission to ensure that there is a coordinated approach so that not all Member States are solely on their own.  There must also be strict rules on safety at work. And the Commission must ensure that sufficient protective equipment is available for everyone in care, in nursing homes, in nursing homes and in hospitals. Because everyone has the right to do their job in a safe way. And everyone also has the right to be surrounded by their loved ones.

name: Jordi CAÑAS
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, if the moral height of a society is measured by the treatment we give to our elders, we must recognise that we have not been up to it. We have not live up to what our elders expect, need, or owe to our elders. We have seen how they have died alone, helpless, abandoned, helpless, distressed, afraid.  This health crisis has confronted our societies in the mirror of reality, and we have seen the best and worst of our societies. We have seen our strengths, but we have also seen our miseries. And it is time to respond to a problem that we have that affects all of us, because they will be us, and we can never let our elders live the anguish and fear of dying alone again, not to be considered first-class citizens. And I propose to you, police station, that from here we all, Members and Commission, should be content to promote a charter of senior rights, to give a clear message, to send a message to our elders that we will never leave them alone again, that they are our priority, that we will always take care of them with the dignity and love they deserve, as long as until the end.

name: Isabella TOVAGLIERI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, in Italy too, as throughout Europe, the impact of the first wave of COVID on long-term illnesses has been more serious than in other health and professional areas, thus forcing us to tighten up all operational protocols. In this new phase, however, the protection of the sick and the elderly in nursing homes will be guaranteed above all by the number and preparation of medical, nursing and paramedical staff who, today as in the past, are at the forefront of assisting the most vulnerable patients and their families. I would like to thank once again this category which, with self-denial and personal risk, has literally kept Italy and all the nations of Europe alive at a particularly dramatic time. Among them there are many young health workers full of energy and passion: they are our future and we must invest in them to effectively face this new pandemic season, avoiding the excessive workloads and stress of the first wave. As a young MEP, I bring to the attention of this House the need for more incentives and funding for the training, stabilisation and careers of these young doctors and nurses, who often lack the right economic and professional recognition for their irreplaceable work. In Italy, the PD/5Stelle government, which often makes up for concrete measures with rhetoric, has called them heroes, only to forget about them, demonstrating short-sightedness and inability to plan strategically. In fact, 10 000 doctors will be missing from the appeal in Italy over the next three years. Yet the University Ministry has just suspended the rankings of the competition for medical specialisation schools, thus lengthening the time taken to enter hospitals and penalising doctors and patients at the same time. I am sure that the European Union can make a difference in this respect. For this reason we ask for its effective and concrete contribution to support healthcare personnel in Italian nursing homes and throughout Europe.

name: Helmut GEUKING
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, of course, my thoughts are with the victims of COVID-19 and their families. And I have to say that we all have to apologise. After all, these problems, which we have had here in the long-term nursing homes, have been known for decades: poor staffing, inadequate staffing, sometimes overcrowding and inadequate care – but not by the will of the nurses, because they are trying, but through job compaction and through bureaucracy and incorrect documentation obligations. That is a fact. I myself am a nursing service manager – I know what I am talking about. As a family party in Germany, we introduced the K21 concept back then, well before COVID-19, years earlier. And there is really only one thing: when I hear "care centers" – completely wrong. What we need is "outpatient before inpatient" for a self-determined life of people. "Ambulant before inpatient" is also a principle in Germany, but is not lived. We must live up to this principle. We wrote it down to the K21 concept years ago. There would have been far fewer deaths. In other words, let us finally stop this policy of failure in care! And one thing very briefly at the end: I always said to my nurse when they asked how they should look after them: "Care for your people the way you want to be cared for. And if you take that into account, you're not doing anything wrong." I believe that we should all take this into account here.

name: Eugenia RODRÍGUEZ PALOP
text: – Mr President, we know that COVID has killed mainly in long-term care facilities, especially in nursing homes, although the information we have is partial and fragmented, because some administrations do not offer data or make-up, unless they lose appeal to their investors ⸺we assume⸺. This is the case of the Community of Madrid in Spain, which has the dubious honour of leading the second wave of contagion in Europe. As far as we know, Madrid has accumulated 9,634 deaths since March, of which 62.67% have died in nursing homes. The management of residences is an exclusive competence of the autonomous communities and in Madrid there has been a real gerontocide: more than 6,000 parents, grandparents, grandmothers, people who have had neither family accompaniment nor farewell. There's a duel that we're going to have to do someday, but we don't just want to live our duel. We want to know, know what has failed, what has happened to these people, and why their caregivers, mostly precarious women, have been completely unprotected, without clear protective equipment or protocols. Well, yes, there was a protocol in Madrid. In March and April, while nursing homes were rejected in public hospitals, their privately insurance colleagues were cared for in private centers. You heard right: the Ministry of Health developed protocols that excluded older terminal-stage residences. The impact of the pandemic has been greater in Madrid because it was in a long process of privatizations and dismantling the public in health matters. And, as that privatization logic continues, Madrid is still in the eye of the hurricane.

name: Mislav KOLAKUŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, almost a year after the pandemic campaign, we still allow the number of deaths from Covid-19 to be established in a completely scientifically unfounded manner and illegally. People who died of heart attacks, strokes are declared dead from Covid-19 only because they tested positive for the corona virus 28 days before, although they showed no signs of the disease.  If we applied that way to a cold, we'd have tens of millions of deaths. What did that lead to? It led to an extreme campaign of fear. We quarantined our oldest people. In Croatia, even in the rest of Europe, half of the people died in nursing homes. On the other hand, hundreds of thousands of citizens of older age were on the Croatian coast this summer, Croatian bathing resorts and almost no one got sick or died.

name: Heléne FRITZON
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr In all our Member States, the pandemic has put a great deal of strain on health care as well as care for the elderly. The staff of these activities, where the majority are women, have made magnificent contributions under very high workloads.  The situation is different in our various Member States. However, the crisis has shown that we have shortcomings for which we must take responsibility, and here all Member States must assume their responsibilities. The responsibility for welfare needs more resources, the responsibility for the fact that we need more staff in health care and care and the responsibility for ensuring that we have secure employment and a good working environment. However, Europe and the EUROPEAN Union also have an important role to play in coordinating and supporting health and health care, and I welcome many of the messages that the Commission has given.  I myself come from a strong welfare country, but also in Sweden requires great efforts in the crisis. My Social Democratic-led government has therefore decided on further efforts in health care and care for the elderly, and that is exactly what we need to do in all Member States. Build a stronger Europe, a stronger prosperity. We all have a common responsibility for that.

name: Barry ANDREWS
text: – Mr President, it can’t go unnoted today that the accidental, but most notorious, long-term care facility in the EU burned down last month, in Moria in Lesbos, but that is a debate we’ve already had. Today, I want to note that at the very beginning of the COVID outbreak, a lot of mistakes were made in relation to nursing homes, particularly around the wearing of masks, advice about allowing visitation, etc. We’ve learned some very hard lessons, as other speakers have said. More than half of the deaths in the EU, according to the WTO, were in nursing homes.  In this second wave, as it appears to be apparent, I think we should also concentrate, as others have said, on people living in long-term residential care with physical and learning disabilities, of whom there are very many. I received an email from a constituent, which I want to quote: ‘we brought our special needs son back to his residential home last week, as my wife and I are totally drained after five months of cocooning. As per rules of the residential home, he has to spend 14 days in isolation in his bedroom’, which underlines the distress for both parents and for patients. I wish to make two quick points. One, we have to make sure that we fund staff with PPE, with testing and with overtime cover and decent wages, and we have to partner with families and listen to older people who know better than anybody else the balance that has to be struck between the loss of emotional and physical contact, and public health on the other hand.

name: Jean-Lin LACAPELLE
text: Mr President, long-term care facilities, i.e. nursing homes and continuing care clinics, are at the heart of the discussion to focus on the effects of coronavirus.  In my country, France, the elderly account for 95% of the deaths we deplore. But in France, what have we done for the elderly? Nothing. We have been cutting budgets, increasing costs, making retirees more vulnerable. The government is now playing a good game of creating a new "dependency" branch of social security, it is in communication and improvisation, as it has been since the beginning of this pandemic. First of all, with the hospital, where 3,400 beds were cut in 2019, we went from downsizing to funding cuts. Caregivers showed their anger in the street for two years, they were never listened to. I would like to point out here that the European Commission, between 2011 and 2018, asked Member States no less than 63 times to cut their health spending. You,50, too, are responsible. As for the Ehpads, during several months of confinement, the dead were not known or counted, abandoned, deprived of protective equipment because of a shortage for which the State is responsible. During the confinement, our elders, already abandoned in institutions lacking resources and staff, were deprived of the visit of their loved ones, sometimes missing them during their last moments. This deplorable picture will only get worse. Demographers predict that the number of dependent seniors will double by 2060. Europe's population in general is aging and shrinking. We need a youth, of course, not only to ensure the care of the elders but also to take over, without which a people cannot live. Far from the amateurism that characterized this crisis management, the situation of health care facilities imposes two conclusions on us. On the one hand, to strengthen assistance to the elderly, not only economically and medically, but also in terms of social and family inclusion. And on the other hand, to initiate a renewal of the European birth rate, which will support and accompany our elders.

name: Margarita DE LA PISA CARRIÓN
text: – Mr President, the situation in the residences of Spain has been dramatic: our elders have been imprisoned.  It's not a metaphor. It is literal: locked, banged, screaming through the doors; their caregivers have been unable to do anything, were without means and had an order from the government to prohibit them from leaving, not even the hospital, evicted. The media has not reflected the real situation; has been silenced. They have been deaths in complete solitude, with deep pain for distance with their relatives. How could it happen? What are the values of a culture that lets its parents die? They who are the reserve of wisdom of our society. The heart of our families. We are facing one of the greatest threats a civilization can face: dehumanization.

name: Chris MACMANUS
text: – A Uachtaráin, is ábhar an-tábhachtach é seo do gach duine againn.  I’ll return to English as unfortunately there are no Irish interpreters available.  COVID—19 outbreaks in care facilities have had a devastating impact on all our communities. In Ireland, we have seen many clusters of COVID in nursing homes, with tragic results. An example of this in my own constituency would be Dealgan Nursing Home, a privately run facility in Dundalk. Last April and May, almost a third of the residents in that nursing home died of COVID. This case really highlights the lack of state oversight in my Member State regarding privately run and profit—driven care facilities, leaving them vulnerable to mismanagement.  There are many similar examples and we need a public inquiry on such matters to learn from this pandemic. Most importantly, it shows that we must, as a society, commit to universal public health and social care that will better protect our communities from communal diseases such as COVID. Go raibh maith agaibh.

name: Pernille WEISS
text: Mr President! You have to be an unlikely callous person if you are not horrified by the too many cases around the EU where residents of care homes have been let down in the most serious way by the crisis. However, as a nurse with many years in the social and health sector, I know that there is a lot of difference between the institutions. These differences are, of course, national, and let us not forget that health and social care is a national responsibility, both in terms of quality and quantity and, above all, economically. I sense a little in the debate that we in this House might be tempted to set a monster of paper tigers free with numbers and heavy reports filled with demands, so that we can try to drag them down on all the countries and all the institutions, because we are certainly trying to generalise, in the good cause, what is also about the culture, competence and governance of each institution in each country. We can then unleash these expensive paper tigers on each other in surely emotional debates in this house, where we can sham countries and hit hundreds of thousands of fantastically skilled employees who make a huge effort every single day. It creates false hopes and creates local responsibility, and none of the citizens of care homes gets anything out of it.  What is needed is for the EU to present itself as the skilled host, coordinator and facilitator for much more cooperation across borders and institutional types to learn from each other and lift each other. So what is the Commission going to do to put in place such an in vain and essentially ethical commitment, and when does the Commission expect residents to feel a clear difference in their everyday lives?

name: Marc ANGEL
text: Mr President, interruption of care, isolation, excessive mental burden, lack of protective equipment and testing, downsizing in long-term care institutions located in the border area in view of the closure of borders, risks of violence and abuse: these are situations faced by people with special needs and health care workers. The impact of the COVID-19 crisis could have been limited if Member States had given Europe the opportunity to impose itself in the coordination of crisis management policies.  Europe can collect data, identify exchanges of good practices, anticipate risks and act in a coordinated manner. That's why the group supports the idea of a Health Union.  Here are our demands: to make social Europe a priority of the European Semester in the same way as financial issues in order to contribute to the refinancing of health care in Europe, put in place a European strategy for people with disabilities, which can provide answers in times of health crisis such as COVID-19, and above all, revise Schengen, so as to guarantee access to cross-border care and mobility of health professionals and to finance the creation of health care institutions community care, particularly in rural areas.

name: Eugen JURZYCA
text: – Mr President, according to the World Health Organisation, in some developed countries, up to 80% of coronavirus deaths are related to long-term justice facilities. However, there are still major differences between Member States in the reporting method, especially with regard to deaths, although the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control has issued a methodology for registering coronavirus cases. However, without high-quality and comparable data, it is not possible to make good choices: without them, for example, we will not be able to ensure that a limited number of vaccines or effective coronavirus medicines are distributed to the people most in need. Therefore, even a small reporting error can put the lives of a very large number of the most vulnerable people at risk.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by First of all, I am pleased that we have taken up today's debate on this important subject. The epidemiological situation in long-term care homes was, especially during the first wave of the pandemic, very bad. In some countries, deaths in these facilities accounted for more than half of all Covid-19 victims. Nursing home residents are, of course, at higher risk, but unfortunately reports from individual countries indicate that many security measures have also been taken too late or insufficiently.  At the moment, the most important thing is to learn from these dramatic events, because it is already clear that the pandemic is still going on and has not yet been overcome, and we still have a long struggle ahead of us. To do this, we also need coordinated action at European level. The biggest challenges need to be clearly identified and how Member States can be supported in crisis management in these facilities. An adequate surveillance system is essential to collect and transmit the necessary data and detect new outbreaks as early as possible in order to maximise transmission between patients and staff.

name: Sara CERDAS
text: – Mr President, bars and other residential units have become one of the main challenges of this pandemic in terms of prevention and control of SARS-CoV-2 infection. I remind you that these are not health units. According to the ECD, one of the main factors contributing to the spread of this virus concerns workers in these units who may have been carriers of the virus or who simply may not have had training and access to adequate equipment and testing in a timely manner. There is therefore an urgent need for a coordinated response to this challenge, to focus on the protection of our most vulnerable, to provide professional and professional carers with adequate training, to step up screening and to engage in good coordination at regional level, at national and At European level, as already requested by this Parliament at the last plenary session. We have to take care of our most vulnerable, but also take care of those who care for them.

name: Patryk JAKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Long-term care centres are primarily people who work there, exceptional people, because, as you know, firstly, they do not earn much, secondly, work at that time was associated with a huge threat to life, and yet they stayed on site to serve the disabled, to serve seniors, to serve the sick. That is why this is a unique kind of solidarity. European solidarity, which we should appreciate and for which, Commissioner, there should be money.  You have talked about many negative cases where people died without any help, you reported cases in Spain. On the other hand, I want to give you a very positive case from the Social Welfare House in Bochnia, Poland, where there was a lack of assistance due to the fact that coronavirus was detected there, but the volunteers came forward dominican sisters who worked there for a long time and helped the sick. It is worth appreciating such people as the Dominican sisters who were there.  We can tell you that we, in Poland, have had many such positive experiences.

name: Miriam LEXMANN
text: – Mr President, the ongoing pandemic has shown us the huge vulnerability of the long-term care system for the elderly and persons with disabilities. We have seen situations where many clients of these devices have succumbed to the coronavirus because access to protective equipment, safe isolation of the sick or testing has not been ensured. All failures, including lack of support for equipment, should therefore be properly and promptly investigated. The pandemic has also shown us that repeated calls for the deinstitutionalisation of long-term care facilities are even more important than ever. Smaller family-type facilities would not only improve clients' chances of a full life, but would also be demonstrably more resilient to epidemiological crises. We therefore need to focus our work in the near term, but also sufficient resources to achieve the objective of the transition from institutional to community-based care. Last but not least, unfortunately, the pandemic has set a mirror for us. We are witnessing the fact that respect for the elderly or acceptance of persons with disabilities has disappeared. The level of society is measured according to how it treats the most vulnerable. However, the pandemic has shown us that our society still has a great deal of work to do to meet the values to which we subscribe.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by There are different countries and different societies. A colleague from the European People's Party has just spoken of the insensitivity of societies. I have the impression that my society, Polish society, reacted in a very thoughtful and humane way. This is what MEP Patryk Jaki has just spoken about.  And you have also reacted in different ways: some have reacted very lightly, others, like my country, but not only my country, have reacted in a very anticipating way. As a result, in my country, Poland, the number of deaths per million inhabitants was twenty times lower than in Belgium, the country where we are. I am impressed by what you from Spain said here. I hope that other Members from Spain will respond to this. Similar situations were also in Belgium.  One more point – we say that the European Union has not responded to this. This is indeed a fact, but in principle there are no european health provisions in the Treaties. Except that the rule of law is not there, too. The Union has therefore fallen into a snare of hypocrisy.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: – Mr President, dear Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, there are deaths in the homes of the European Union, in my country, in Portugal, which should have been, and could have been avoided. There was sloth, there was incompetence, there was inertia from governments. I know it is a national competence, but the European Union too must coordinate and do more and the Commissioner's words are encouraging and give hope to that effect. We need coordination in health, but we also need a real plan and pact to combat loneliness in the European Union. We were worth the excellent health professionals and also the excellent professionals who work in ipss and mercies, often destiture. Here is also a challenge: Member States will receive billions of euros, for example in the recovery fund. It is also essential to use these resources to protect the most vulnerable, to help those who need it most and the funds that go to the Member States should also have a goal in this area. We have an average age of about 44 years, has a tendency to increase, it is something that forces us to act and we need to age with quality, it is not enough to last much longer.

name: Sunčana GLAVAK
text: – Dear Chairman, according to the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, coronavirus-related deaths among long-term care facility service users represent 30-60% of deaths from Covid-19.  Many people with long-term care need have been isolated in homes for weeks, leading to reduced social contact, disrupted and changed routines, fear and anxiety. Because of their protection, they are socially excluded, they are victims of social isolation, solitude and exclusion are particularly stressful for them. It's a generation, though, that doesn't live in the digital world. Worryingly, the World Health Organisation's report on the impact of Covid-19 shows that violence against the elderly has risen sharply since the pandemic began.  We need to encourage Member States to provide mental and emotional support, as well as psychosocial assistance, but not least, financial support. Reduce social isolation, but saving a life is a new challenge that often excludes each other. I hope that the European Commission will take this into account in the Green Paper on Ageing, which you mentioned in your address, Vice-President, to consider the etiability of social protection systems and active ageing policies, as well as long-term care policies. How much we take care of our elderly fellow citizens will be a mirror of our humanity and humanity - because today you and I are one day older, and the people we are talking about tomorrow will be us!

name: Benoît LUTGEN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the situation was dramatic in many care facilities and nursing homes during the pandemic, particularly in my country, Belgium. The question is, therefore, fundamental: what is the place of seniors in our society? And what measures should be put in place in the Member States and at European level to better support close caregivers, to get more recognition, to respect the freedom of choice of older people to go or not to go to care and rest homes, to support family helpers and all health actors in order to enable as many elderly people as possible to stay at home , in their living environment.  This is obviously a very important element in a more comprehensive strategy that could be developed at EU level. The rate in Belgium of people present in nursing homes is very important, many find themselves there without really having chosen it or because we did not take enough account of all the actors that would allow these elderly people to stay at home and to maintain this freedom and serenity to live at home. I think it is an important axis, we cannot isolate the reality of nursing homes, we need to be able to see this more comprehensively on the whole issue and concern for seniors and seniors in our society by supporting very strongly, including caregivers, caregivers, home helpers, home helpers.

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: – Dear Chairman, while researching the details on the topic of this debate, I remained stunned. Up to 66% of covid-19 deaths in some countries have so far been wards of long-term care facilities. And it's terrible. Then, what is even scarier, and what has been seen through this debate are the differences between individual Member States in this regard. Differences in standards, in service availability, in how this service is provided.  Here we have heard many times from colleagues that the European Union has no competence, no possibility to act. That's partly true, but not to the end. Namely, there is a recovery fund that is financed, that is, that will finance the repair of the consequences of the pandemic. It has a European Social Fund that can help finance the training of the workforce in social welfare institutions. We have a European Regional Development Fund that can finance health infrastructure.   Thus, there are financial instruments by which the European Union can greatly contribute to reducing these differences in the quality of long-term care. And finally, there is the European Semester as a mechanism for controlling whether countries meet those standards for which they have undertaken the commitment themselves. Thus, the European Union can do a lot in equaling the quality of long-term care in the European Union and thus can show that the life of all citizens of the European Union is worth the same. I am also very pleased that the European Commission and through vice-president Šuica's portfolio show that this is a priority and I believe that this will continue because after all we will all come to those years sometime and we must show that the lives of all citizens in the European Union are equally important.

name: Salvatore DE MEO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there have been around 3.00 million people in the european Union as a whole who have died of COVID-19 and almost 200 000. The numbers continue to grow and in this war bulletin the statistics tell us that the facilities that welcome the elderly and differently able people have become clusters of spread of the virus and that health workers have risked, and in some cases sacrificed, their own lives to save those of others. It is necessary to analyze these data in order to understand, even with the establishment of a committee of inquiry, what may have been the critical issues that have increased the risk conditions of contagion in these structures, which cannot be considered human peripheries. It is our duty to call for a review of the procedures for the reception and management of care homes for disabled elderly people: we need to imagine new European protocols to better protect vulnerable people and enable health professionals to better face the new challenge, which is now almost close. COVID is still among us and we must not be found unprepared.

name: Antonius MANDERS
text: Mr President, I would like to congratulate Commissioner Šuica on the dignity with which she has described this problem in her contribution. COVID-19 has taken us by storm and we have seen that COVID-19 has caused many casualties as a result of the system, which is actually created by neoliberalism, in which everyone approaches society individually and in which we pigeonhole older and weak people, as long as they are away from society.  I welcome the Commissioner's commitment to a Green Paper to improve the health system at European level. I hope that this will mean a single market for healthcare, that it would mean that the EU would have the competence for care, in an integral sense, and I hope that there will also be a minimum price for medicines and medical products throughout Europe.  Then we will also have to make people healthier, because 50% of the population is over 50. The other half want to be it, so we have to make sure we create a healthier society. Life-sustaining building is important.  The setting aside of the elderly has led to the problems we know, and I have been extremely angry about a journalist who wrote in the Netherlands: "The arid wood is being cut down, maybe a few months earlier than without the virus." That is a great shame and I think that journalists, as opinion-makers, should respect the dignity of all people.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, once again, I thank the honourable Members for this important debate on the impact of COVID—19 on long-term care facilities. Those affected include the elderly, and I take this opportunity to welcome the work of the German Presidency on the rights of the elderly in digitalisation, which was mentioned by one or two Members. Member States are aware that active ageing also means being able to fully participate in society. Today we inhabit a more digitalised world. Digitalisation and technology help older people in their autonomy and ability to connect with others. It also raises issues on the right to privacy. This calls for action in increasing digital literacy for older people. Digital tools must be accessible and easy to use for all ages. Those who are unable to use them must be provided with alternative ways of accessing essential services. The fundamental rights and values of the European Union are indivisible, universal values of human dignity, freedom, equality and solidarity. These rights are valid throughout the whole life cycle, from birth to death. In my role as Vice—President for Democracy and Demography, the whole of the live cycle is the focus of my work, and I have to think about the most vulnerable in our policy-making, particularly when we consider long-term care facilities. I see that you share these views and would like to address some points raised here today. There were questions on Article 19 from Ms Metz on implementation and on funding. I would like to answer that the Commission is committed to the entire European Pillar of Social Rights. In order to deliver, we will present, next year, an action plan on the implementation of the European Pillar of Social Rights. Regarding funding, someone said that there is no reference in the Treaty on European Union responsibilities, but there is the Coronavirus Response Investment Initiative and, of course, the European Union Recovery and Resilience Facility. Then, as I mentioned in my introductory statement, there is REACT-EU, but also don’t forget that we are negotiating the Multiannual Financial Framework. Also, of course, there is the European Social Fund, and I am aligned with those who said that the European Semester can also be one of the tools. Mr Brglez mentioned the quality standards for long-term care. I mentioned the Green Paper consultation at the beginning, so let’s discuss which measures are required and at which level – at European level and at Member State level. We will need to take a close look at long-term care, and I’m totally in alignment with you. Regarding a stronger role for the European Union in health care and long—term care, you will remember the State of the Union address by our President, Ursula von der Leyen, which was held here two weeks ago. She mentioned health. So let’s use the Conference on the Future of Europe to discuss the role of health and the role of the European Union: what can we do and what can we improve? Because almost all of you were talking about this. So I think this Conference on the Future of Europe, which will be launched soon, may be one of the instruments through which we can debate this important issue. The COVID—19 pandemic exposed gaps in long-term care, showing a lack of coordination of services between healthcare and long—term care providers, and of course this resulted in difficulties for home residents to access health services, including patients with COVID—19 and patients with chronic conditions. The pandemic and containment measures also intensified loneliness. Many of you mentioned loneliness, solitude and isolation. We are completely aware that loneliness is a phenomenon, and we will definitely tackle this issue. There is psychological distress here too, not only among older people, but among all users of these facilities. The service providers themselves – the carers – have had to work under extremely difficult conditions, improvising on many levels in their efforts to go above and beyond the call of duty. Effective care management through the involvement and collaboration of clinicians, patients, users and caregivers is necessary. It can form the cornerstone in the transformation of health and long—term care systems in providing services that are adapted to the needs, values and preferences of the users, while supporting the providers. Once again, I cannot forget the images of isolation, loneliness and grief that emerged from our long-term care homes across the European Union. In some places it is still happening. We must strive to ensure that no one has to experience the loss of a loved one in such a traumatic way ever again. By pulling together, we can demonstrate the value of our solidarity by providing the long-term care sector with the support they need, which in turn helps build a better society for all of us. This requires efforts on all sides, as many of you said – at European level, at Member State level, among regional and local authorities, and, yes, at a societal and individual level. Thank you once again for this debate. I am looking forward to cooperation in the future.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Ioan-Rareş BOGDAN
text: in writing. – In situations of health crisis, some people are more vulnerable than others. I am referring here to the elderly and those with disabilities. When it comes to care services, we cannot help the categories that benefit from them if we do not support those who offer them. That is why it is essential to strike a better balance between prosperity, public health and security.  It is necessary to have well-trained and financially stimulated care staff, but also institutions that support vulnerable people and where they feel safe and have decent conditions of care. It is absolutely imperative that we provide equal access so that all European citizens can receive health care in a sustainable way.  In this context, I would like to thank with all my heart the care staff who have made and continue to work hard and who have done their exemplary duty in the face of a critical situation arising from the COFID-19 pandemic. Now, more than ever, patient safety and quality must be our number one priority. That is why we must fight for better protection and funding of these care institutions.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The coronavirus epidemic has broad and far-reaching consequences for society as a whole, but the situation in long-term care facilities requires special attention. A significant proportion of residents of such institutions are elderly people, who, due to their age, are at high risk of acute illness and death. At the same time, the risk of transmission of the virus in care facilities is very high due to the close contact of residents with other people. A sharp increase in the number of cases in such centres can place too much strain on local hospitals, resulting in poorer healthcare for the most vulnerable group in society. It should be borne in mind that isolating the elderly in such facilities is not an option. The ban on visits and group activities adversely affects mental health, and isolation increases the risk of neglect and sometimes abuse of the elderly. It is not possible to bring about a situation in which the elderly are abandoned and left to themselves. Caring for the health and life of the elderly is a moral duty for all of us and an element of the solidarity we need today. It is not possible to bring about situations known from Belgium or the Netherlands where the elderly were refused assistance because the priority was to care for the younger ones. Measures should be put in place to ensure safety, care and comfort in facilities for the most vulnerable groups.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: in writing. – COVID-19 has exposed the weaknesses that exist in some Member States in Continuing Care Units whose response to the needs of the population is very insufficient. The many shortcomings in the provision of care at this level, as far as human capacity and means are concerned, are not now: the problem already existed; the virus just exposed it. The aging of a significant part of the population should lead to these areas being considered important or priority, also conditioning the need for greater integration of primary care with hospital. Continued care units have long been required to be strengthened by creating integrated networks in public services, in conjunction with primary health care. The model of contracting services with the social and private sector creates many difficulties in accessing the necessary care in the appropriate time and places. If we want to provide integrated continuous care to people who, regardless of age, are in a situation of dependency, then other policies are needed to enable public investment and the strengthening of means, capable of ensuring universal, accessible and quality responses to all those in need of this care.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: Written. –The World Health Organisation(WHO) European Agency has estimated that in the spring, in the first wave of COVID-19, up to half of the deaths related to the virus in Europe occurred in care homes. This must be thoroughly investigated and any omissions and errors must be dealt with transparently. The EU should set up a research committee to investigate what happened in care homes during the first wave of coronavirus. It is very worrying that, in a situation where only around 0.5% of the European population, or 3.7 million Europeans, live in retirement homes, half of the deaths related to the coronavirus occurred.  We must protect our elderly from the coronavirus. We cannot allow what happened in the spring to happen again. Even before the coronavirus pandemic, the operations of many care homes, their resourcing and the level of care were in a bad way. Reports of European care homes have been arresting reading: those affected by the coronavirus have not been taken to the doctor or treated properly. We must seek a common European solution that guarantees care for all Europeans that respect human rights and fundamental rights. The EU needs a common care strategy that provides choice and sufficient resources to organise care.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Eritrea, the case of Dawit Isaak (2020/2813(RSP)).

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: author. – Mr President, I want to make a point of order first, because we had this problem also at the last plenary session. In the urgencies from the session previous to this one, the order was not the d’Hondt method. The colleagues asked for it to be like that last session, and I would request that we keep to that. So I’m glad to talk, but I would be the last, following the d’Hondt method.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: I called in the order in which the motions were tabled because it’s a long—term practice in the plenary to do it this way, and I would like to stick to it. I am, of course, open to changes. However, I think that the political groups should agree first on a different practice if we change it. I don’t think that it’s a good idea to change it for one debate this way and for another debate another way. So I would like to stick to the order that I called for.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: author. – I can stick to the order, but it was not my request last plenary. It was a request from the colleagues from EPP and S&D, and I agree with them, because normally the order was the d’Hondt method and not the order of tabling the resolutions. In any case, I don’t want to lose any more time. If you think that the order is the one to follow, okay, but it was not the agreement of the colleagues last session, and we changed the order last session in order that the urgencies would be according to the d’Hondt method. So I don’t know what the colleagues have to say, but if it is the case, so I’ll take the floor – or we can follow the regular order.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: Please have the floor. As I said, I am open to changes if the political groups agree at the COP level. I’m not willing to change the long—term practice just for...

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: author. It is not a long-term practice. But in any case, I'm going to start and I'm going to speak in English. I'm sorry for this.  – Mr President, Dawit Isaak, an Eritrean citizen but also a Swede, was arrested for the first time in 2001. He was never brought to trial and was never charged. However, during the regime of Isaiah Afewerki, thousands of people have been detained for their political views or their work as independent journalists.  In this resolution what we do is demand to know what is going on with Dawit Isaak and call for the immediate and unconditional release of all prisoners of conscience in Eritrea. It is a basic measure in line with international law. We also regret that Eritrea does not leave any room for action to human rights defenders, members of the political opposition or independent journalists.  In this regard, we call on the whole of Parliament to take a stand. As I said, since 2001, Mr. Isaak has been in custody and, although he has been released a few times, the truth is that he is always back in prison. Your family doesn't know about him. You are a citizen of the European Union, we have an obligation to have answers.

name: Lars Patrick BERG
text: author. – Mr President, first of all, let me say that I fully support the campaign regarding Dawit Isaak. I think we also need to reaffirm our support for the right to freedom of belief. On a much wider note, I think the Member States need to review policy regarding Eritrea, and in particular our financial support that keeps this despotic regime in power. Their reliance on the national service law, which is in fact modern slavery, ensures a fearful and compliant population. Their intimidation of any opposition, including deadly force, should be no longer tolerated. Eritrea’s foreign policy, such as it is, serves to destabilise an already desperate region. The Member States need to come together to agree a policy on Eritrea, Ethiopia, Somalia, and not simply provide support to maintain the status quo.

name: Evin INCIR
text: author. – Mr President, first and foremost, I want to thank all my colleagues for the good cooperation that has made this resolution possible – an urgency that talks about real people’s lives, because oppression and injustice are not only words. Right now, and for 19 years, the Swedish and European journalist and citizen, Dawit Isaak, has been unlawfully imprisoned by the oppressing regime in Eritrea. For 19 years, his wife and his children have tried to do everything they can to get him released.  Dreaming and peacefully acting for democracy must never be a crime. There is something rotten in the world when people can be jailed and in the worst cases, be deprived of their lives, just because they dream of a better society, a better world. Dawit Isaak must immediately receive all the help he can get, both medical and consular. Firm action is now required. We demand the immediate release of Dawit Isaak and all other political prisoners, journalists, opposition and innocent civilians. Martin Luther King wisely once said: ‘In the end, we will remember not the words of our enemies, but the silence of our friends.’  To Dawit Isaak and his family, I just want to say that you have many friends in this Parliament and we will not stay silent until the day Dawit Isaak is back home in Sweden in safety.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Author. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The problem is wider. Of course, our Parliament is doing well, demanding, above political divisions, the release of a man who has spent so many years in prison. After all, he has the nationality of one of the Member States of the European Union. But it's not just about him, it's about the broader problem of the persecution of religious groups by the Eritrean authorities, specifically Christians, Catholics, and that happens all the time. By calling for the release of Dawit Isaac, we should also very strongly demand an end to the religious persecution of people who profess their faith and have every right to do so. It is good that the European Parliament is speaking on this issue, but this is not , I stress very strongly, an isolated matter. Such repressive actions by the Eritrean authorities have been going on for a long time and deserve absolute condemnation. In my opinion, this must be done very clearly.

name: Arba KOKALARI
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr It has been 19 years since the Swedish Eritrean journalist Dawit Isaak was imprisoned in Eritrea. He never got a trial or a conviction. He was imprisoned for using his fundamental human right, his freedom of expression. He had the courage to criticise the Eritrean Government and to demand democratic reforms.  This summer, however, we received signs that Dawit Isaak is still alive. It's incredibly hopeful. That is precisely why the work to get him released now needs to be stepped up, and that is why we are now trying to gather broad support in the European Parliament for his release. Europe and the rest of the world must raise their voices against the regime in Eritrea, and we must ensure that our aid does not go to the Eritrean Government, in a country that is very much dependent on aid.  Journalists and human rights defenders are imprisoned around the world. We must not allow them to fall into oblivion, because that is exactly what regimes like Eritrea want them to be forgotten. But we will not forget and we will not be silent. Because the message to the Eritrean Government must be clear from the EU: let Dawit Isaak free now!

name: Karin KARLSBRO
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr 6,955 days, 6,955 nights, so long has the Swedish Eritrean journalist Dawit Isaak been imprisoned in Eritrea without trial. He has not been allowed to see his family, no lawyer, nor any diplomats in the meantime. We take it for granted here. But elsewhere in the world, it can get you locked up for 19 years. The cruelty, repression and violations of human rights and human rights and human rights and human rights by the Eritrean regime are unprecedented.  Dawit Isaak is a European citizen. His business is the european Union's business. It is the EU's duty to do everything for his freedom. This is a high priority for the EU's Foreign Affairs Commissioner, for Mr Borrell. The European Union must step up pressure on Eritrea to release Dawit Isaak and all other prisoners of conscience. Freedom of the media and freedom of expression must be respected.  In recent years, Eritrea has received many millions of euros in aid from the EU. This must be stopped. Our common resources should never finance dictatorships and oppression. But there is hope. Dawit's daughter Bethlehem told me last summer that her father is alive. Now help us get Dawit home to his family, where he belongs. Free Dawit Now!

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Nineteen years – so much without any trial, even without charges, spent in prison Dawit Isaak, journalist, writer and two-time finalist of the Sakharov Prize. He was thrown into prison after publishing an open letter calling for democratic reforms. Twenty-one other people were arrested and then all independent media were outlawed. It was therefore an overt and brutal attack on freedom of expression.  Today we call on the Eritrean Government to immediately release Dawit Isaac and other prisoners of conscience. Furthermore, we demand that the European Union have the opportunity to contact a imprisoned journalist who is also a citizen of the European Union, as well as to have access to information on his state of health and the possibility of providing him with support. Without free media and respect for human rights, there is no democracy. We therefore call on the Eritrean Government to restore the democratic order, to guarantee the free functioning of the media and to restore the rule of law, which does not allow innocent citizens to be imprisoned.  At the same time, until the necessary changes are implemented, we must not allow EU funds to support the Eritrean Government. This support should go directly to the citizens of the country and support democracy, human rights and humanitarian action.

name: Maria ARENA
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Mr. President, the Dawit Isaak case is emblematic of the situation in Eritrea, which is one of the harshest military dictatorships in the world. In this dictatorship, forced labour is organized institutionally by the authorities, with this famous system of unlimited national service. European support for Eritrea should never contribute to this forced labour. However, by financing this country through development aid, by financing its roads without making sure that their construction is not based on this forced labour, we are complicit in this practice. Moreover, no migrants should be able to be returned to this country, considered the most repressive in the world. Yet IOM, with the support of the European Union, has sent dozens of Eritreans back to their country, guaranteeing them the imprisonment and thus the same abuse and abuse of journalist Dawit Isaak in Eritrean prisons. So, yes, we must raise our voices in the face of what is happening in Eritrea, but we must also be responsible for our actions, both on the issue of development cooperation and on the issue of the return of migrants to that country.

name: Abir AL-SAHLANI
text: On the other: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Authoritarian regimes around the world believe that they can imprison free thought, free speech, to silence their people, to deprive them of their voice. Dawit Isaak uses his voice, his human right, for freedom of expression, which is why he has been imprisoned for 19 years. Jailed for 19 years without trial, without contact with the outside world. For 19 years, Dawit Isaak hasn't been able to be a father to his children.  I know our world is shaken up right now, and we have many challenges. But free speech is no exception. It is also persecuted here on our own continent, even here in the only Union of democracies.  There are heroes, those who work tirelessly, who fight every day for free speech. Dawit Isaak, who is still standing today, after 19 years, is such a hero, and we must not forget his struggle in this house. I therefore expect nothing less from the European Parliament than to take a clear stand on the free speech and to demand immediately that Dawit Isaak be released and that the Government of Asmara stop all violations of human rights. Free Dawit Isaak Now!

name: Alice KUHNKE
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for "I want to say goodbye to you, my reader, until I see you again in the next story. There's another book coming. I say goodbye for this time." This is what Dawit Isaak wrote. But there have not been enough texts since then, since he has been imprisoned for 19 years. 6,955 days in prison. There's a lot of us who haven't given up. We will continue the fight for Dawit Isaak, for his family and for justice. Free Dawit Isaak!

name: Patryk JAKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Eritrea exhibits all the characteristics of a totalitarian state, both in terms of state system, non-elections, sittings of parliament, lack of freedom, freedom at all, as well as the press, opposition activities, lack of processes, abuse of power. David Isaak, whom we are discussing today, is precisely the symbol of this type of behaviour. Not only is he imprisoned for more than 20 years, it is in addition without trial, without the right to defend himself, without reliable information about the state of his health.  I therefore join all my colleagues in this House in requesting that the European Union stand firm in defence of this and other political prisoners in this regime. I also believe that it is precisely these matters that we should devote a great deal of time to when we are talking about freedom of expression, about the fundamental values that the European Union creates. We should fight for such people all the more because this is also a Swedish citizen, and that is why it is our commitment.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Dawit Isaak, as many colleagues in this house have mentioned, has been imprisoned for 19 years. For 19 years he has been deprived of the right to be a father, for 19 years the world has been deprived of his voice. For 19 years, we have failed to save him, thus devising journalists across the world from a brave colleague. Every day in prison is an unforgivable theft, from Dawit, from his family and for the world who needs brave journalists, now more than ever. I am pleased that we of the European Parliament are once again calling for dawit Isaak and the other Eritrean prisoners of conscience to be released with immediate effect, and for us to immediately have proof that they are alive. Seven of the 28 who were imprisoned at the same time as Dawit Isaak have already died. We Swedish Social Democrats will continue to fight for justice for Dawit Isaak, and I know that many in this house feel the same way.  We need to get him released. It was a hope to hear his daughter tell him he's alive this summer. Let's keep telling you about Dawit Isaak and saving him.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Madam President, I wanted to speak on Eritrea because I think it is really North Korea of Africa. Take the case of Dawit Isaak: this journalist and opponent has been detained in Eritrean jails for 19 years. We don't know anything about these jails. A woman named Ciham Ali has been held there incommunicado since the age of 15. Thousands of people share their plight and are detained for expressing their political ideas. However, nothing has changed since 1993 in Eritrea: there is still no rule of law or constitution, there are arbitrary detentions, torture, ongoing violations of rights...  But I would like to draw your attention to the position of the European Commission. I spoke in the Committee on Budgetary Control and in the Committee on Development because I noticed that the Commission had given EUR 80 million to restore roads. However, you know that the Commission is giving money without conditionality at the moment. And we, as MEMBERS of the European Parliament, cannot accept this as we fight for human rights. And there is no way that we should continue to subsidize a dictatorship.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, the European Union has been following the case of Dawit Isaak from the outset and remains concerned about his whereabouts and health. We have shared these concerns with the authorities in Eritrea on numerous occasions. Violations of human rights, including the arbitrary detention of political prisoners and non-respect for freedom of speech and the media, are of continued concern to us. We have addressed them and will continue to do so. We have raised these concerns bilaterally and at the appropriate international fora, such as the Human Rights Council, urging the government of Eritrea to take concrete steps to address and remedy them. But we can not only criticise. We have to engage proactively to promote positive change. This is not something that happens overnight. It requires continued energetic efforts. I believe that our robust engagement on the political and cooperation track has improved bilateral relations, increased the level of trust and allowed us to discuss sensitive issues with a view to improving respect for human rights. We do that in the interest of improving the living conditions of the people of Eritrea and increasing our ability to promote reforms. Results, however small, bring us closer to where we would like to be. The bilateral engagement on human rights between the Government of Eritrea and Eamon Gilmore, our Special Representative for Human Rights; Eritrea’s engagement within the Human Rights Council’s Universal Periodic Review; and our support to help them implement some of the recommendations they have accepted are concrete cases in point. The European Union looks forward to Eritrea’s action plan on the recommendations and is making good progress with the Government to start activities soon. I trust that, by engaging in dialogue and exploring ways to work together, we stand a better chance to make our voice heard and to positively influence the country’s human rights record, promote the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms, and advance the case of Dawit Isaak.
