name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The Dawit Isaak case demonstrates on the one hand the extreme precariousness of the status of independent journalist in some countries and, on the other hand, the limits of European diplomacy, characterized in this case by the "silent" offensive (perhaps too much?) of Sweden since the early 2000s. In fact, Eritrea is still one of the most repressive regimes in the world. In 2015, Reporters Without Borders awarded it the last place in its press freedom ranking, while the cults remain subject to close government control. This oppression irrigates society as a whole, through a national service that is frequently abused and almost akin to a new form of slavery. Every year, he pushes countless nationals of this small African country into the arms of human traffickers and on global migration routes. In this regard, if Europeans and other major powers cannot be held accountable for all the atrocities committed around the world, or indeed solve them, we should at least refrain from participating, even indirectly, through, for example, the promotion of infrastructure projects that could give way to gross violations of fundamental rights.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The next item is a debate on five motions for a resolution on the Nicaraguan Law on 'Foreign Agents' (2020/2814(RSP)).

name: Tilly METZ
text: author. – Madam President, the proposed Law on Foreign Agents comes after weeks of increased repression against activists and human rights defenders in Nicaragua. Especially women activists face growing violence and intimidation, including sexual violence and threats on social media. This law, together with the proposed Special Law on Cybercrime, could have a negative impact on the right to equal political and public participation and lead to unlawful criminalisation of civil society organisations, activists and human rights defenders. Numerous NGOs have expressed their concern. I hope that their voices will be heard and that the Congress of Nicaragua rejects these laws. Repression of the opposition and silencing their voices is not the way forward. Dialogue is. I call on the Government of Nicaragua and all parties concerned to engage in a meaningful and comprehensive national dialogue to come to an agreement of electoral reforms that would guarantee credible, inclusive and transparent elections next year.

name: Alicia HOMS GINEL
text: Author. – Madam President, Nicaragua's citizenship has been living in unacceptable circumstances for too long. Daniel Ortega's government has given up defending its people and clinging to power at the expense of the majority.  From the European Parliament, we call on the Government of Nicaragua to abandon the authoritarian path of repression. If they continue to restrict the rights of their citizens, there will be consequences, such as new sanctions. Withdraw laws that violate human rights, such as foreign agents, cease hostilities against those who say what they think, release those detained for expressing their ideas, and let back those who have had to go into exile for fighting for Nicaragua in which they believe. Return to the democratic channel, return to national dialogue and take on the necessary reforms so that the next elections can be free and fair. From Europe, many encouragements to all those who resist day by day, to all those groups that are threatened, such as all women who, in addition to political repression, also suffer from gender-based violence and sexual abuse.  For many miles that separate us, we will continue to fight to help you regain your rights; we are joined by our struggle for democracy, for freedom and for social justice. We are on your side, on the side of those who fight for plural Nicaragua, where they all fit, regardless of their gender, origins or ideas. And only through dialogue can this Nicaragua be built.

name: José Ramón BAUZÁ DÍAZ
text: Author. – Madam President, Nicaragua is currently at a turning point: either the path of reforms and commitment to a free and transparent election in 2021, or the path Ortega has followed, which undoubtedly leads us to an election with electoral fraud. So, let's not kid ourselves. What do we think is going to happen in Nicaragua if the democratic path closes? Haven't we learned enough from what happened in Venezuela? With this resolution we send a clear and clear message to the high representative and also to the Council: in Nicaragua there must already be democratic change. And otherwise, if there isn't, there have to be consequences. If Ortega continues his attack on democracy and human rights, the European Union must act quickly and clearly. What is required in this Resolution? Two fundamental things are required: the sanctions on Ortega and Murillo and their entire criminal gang, and also the activation of the democratic clause of the Association Agreement. In 2012 we committed all Democrats in the European Parliament to suspend the Association Agreement if human rights were not fulfilled if democracy was not fulfilled. How many dead, how many exiles must there be in Nicaragua for us to continue to be ashamed and distinguished? Ladies and gentlemen, if Ortega and Murillo want to keep stealing what little is left of the people of Nicaragua, other than with our collusion. That is why today the European Parliament does its duty, it fulfils its function, that is, today we fulfil our mandate. Now is the time for Mr Borrell and the Council to also comply.

name: Leopoldo LÓPEZ GIL
text: Author. – Madam President, today we are facing a clear attempt by the dictatorship to continue to suppress fundamental rights and freedoms in Nicaragua: the Law on the Regulation of Foreign Agents, promoted by the deputies of the Sandinista Alliance for National Liberation, which we are now debating, together with the Law against Hate Crimes and the Special Law on Cybercrime , are the clear strategy of that Ortega regime to legally prevent the participation of the opposition in future elections and to remain in power by being kept in an alleged rule of law.  These three laws would not only distort the political system in Nicaragua, but would support persecution and harassment of political opposition and censorship of digital media and allow the imposition of life imprisonment by political dissent. If passed, the Foreign Agents Regulation Act could be used as a sanctioning instrument against human rights persons and organizations receiving international cooperation resources, including those of the European Union. Initiatives such as these bills demonstrate that there is no intention on the part of the authoritarian Government of Nicaragua to cease its violation of human rights.  The European Union has a duty to react to these provocations. Let us activate the resources available to us by invoking the democratic clause of the Association Agreement between the European Union and the countries of Central America.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: Author. – Madam President, we have in Nicaragua another case of a dictatorship that we are treating too well. And that dictatorship is growing, precisely because of the treatment it favors, and it is crushing and creating situations in which it is really closing the cage more and more to its people; is killing its population.  Continuously, since 2017, we have had an escalation of brutal repression. We now have laws in view, which have been introduced, to absolutely close the discussion: both the Foreign Agents Regulation Act, which assumes that there will be virtually no possible international cooperation, and the Special Cybercrime Act, which will leave no opinion or hard work there. This is a dictatorship that we have to treat as such, as we have to deal with that of Cuba, which has so much influence in Nicaragua. Please, the high representative has to send a clear signal here; venezuela and Nicaragua, Venezuela and Cuba.

name: Isabel BENJUMEA BENJUMEA
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Nicaragua has been suffering for too long by an enemy government of freedom, democracy and human rights. And that is because Nicaragua suffers from a communist government, a Sandinista, Marxist, revolutionary government, belonging to this alliance ill known as "21st century socialism", a group of totalitarian governments that we must fight without shortcuts or concessions, if we really want to export to the world our model of liberal democracy, respect for individual freedoms and human rights. Let us not make a mistake, so often made throughout history, of wanting to content, through transfer, insatiable ideologies. I therefore support this Resolution and the agreement reached on its content by the firm condemnation of that regime in the enemy of freedom. However, I cannot help but mention that I am powerfully striking at how easily we use the term "far right" in this House and how we are unable to use the term "far left", which does not appear at any time throughout the text. Not a single reference in the text. As mentioned above, this Nicaraguan social-community government has introduced two bills through the Sandinista forces, which support it. Two projects that want to shut the opposition up. Two projects that want to silence the opposition, who cannot fight and defend the rights of citizens. I would therefore like to ask that the European Union strongly condemn these two laws, show its support for the Nicaraguan opposition and say 'live the freedom'.

name: Maria-Manuel LEITÃO-MARQUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, the Covid-19 crisis has left thousands of victims and exacerbated inequalities in Latin America. The worst that could happen there, as here, is that, moreover, COVID was also a pretext for suppressing fundamental rights and freedoms. That's what's happening in Nicaragua. The three proposals under discussion, the foreign agents law, the cybercrime and fake news law, and the changing penalties for hate crimes deepen President Ortega's authoritarian drift. In view of this situation, the European Union can only respond firmly and clearly, not by agreeing with this serious violation of human rights. However, a diplomatic break serves not the interests of the Union or nicaraguans. That is why we will do everything to support Nicaragua's civil society, to find a way of dialogue, ensuring that the hope of moving this country on the path to democracy remains alive.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, in the Sandinista Revolution, the fight against the tyrant Anastasio Somoza sounded good. In my memory it is associated with the songs of Carlos Mejía Godoy, cheerful, hopeful. Today they can only be heard with nostalgia. Daniel Ortega's government destroyed these scores. Today, it is a corrected and increased reflection of the dictatorship he overthrew. The agreements reached in 2019 to seek a peaceful, dialogued and lasting way out of an unprecedented crisis, organize free elections and resume coexistence have been left in the water of erasure. And the responsibility for failure is those who promote laws such as the regulation of so-called "foreign agents" or those who, under the excuse of combating cybercrime, sanctify censorship; both flagrant violation of basic democratic principles and international treaties signed by Nicaragua; both delve deeper into the repressive drift denounced by all kinds of international organizations and human rights defenders.  That is why I express my support and solidarity to the victims of repression. In addition, I support sanctions on the hierarchies of this criminal regime and the sending of a parliamentary mission there as soon as possible. I applaud the Union's commitment to human rights defenders, independent media, democratic opposition and all who work there for peace and coexistence. In short, it is a question of requiring the immediate and full compliance with Nicaragua of the clauses of the Association Agreement between the Union and the central American countries focused on the defence of the rule of law.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, since the ferocious repression of social movements in April 2018, Nicaragua seems to have been caught up in an endless authoritarian drift. We are rightly talking about NGOs and other organizations with foreign funding. They will now be overseen by close government tutelage at the end of a bill of 22 September 2020. There is less talk, in fact, of the Catholic Church, which is the target of verbal and physical attacks by President Ortega and his supporters. The question that Archbishop Carlos Avilés Canton evokes persecution should, however, challenge us, at a time when, from the Middle East to the Western world, Christianity is one of the most oppressed religion in the world. More absent from our debates, too, is the bill on so-called fake news, now punishable by up to four years in prison. Thus, the fallacious pretext of misinformation will have made many emulations to permanently muzzle freedom of expression. And in this respect, Nicaragua is a borderline and caricatured case of a dramatic and general decline in our fundamental rights.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Our parliament, which is arguing on various issues, seems to be united on this issue – and that is a good thing. This is an important and necessary signal to our friends in Nicaragua who are fighting for freedom of expression, for freedom of demonstration, for such fundamental rights as my colleague has just spoken about. I think it has to be said here that this is not a prank on the part of the Nicaraguan authorities, but something that happens there all the time. This pressure on our part must be concrete. This means that a resolution is not enough here, and it must be made very clear here that if the regime in Nicaragua does not abandon such a policy as it stands, then sanctions will follow from us, for example, a blacklist of people who cannot enter the European Union from Nicaragua. It's about the politicians of this country.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, from the European Parliament today, once again, we strongly denounce the authoritarian drift of the current President Ortega in Nicaragua and, in particular, we do so because we understand that the battery of legislative measures, including the Law on the Regulation of Foreign Agents, is another twist on an unacceptable repression and persecution of political dissent, disrespect for pluralism and , above all, disrespect for freedom of expression and freedom of the press.  We call, from the European Parliament, for the cessation of hostilities against civil society and political dissent in Nicaragua and for the intelligent use of all our tools, such as Europeans, to put pressure on the Government of Nicaragua in the current situation: all diplomatic tools at our disposal. For what? For electoral reforms, reforms in the country, to ensure a fair electoral competition, which democratically guarantees the opposition and civil society that they can compete in freedom; on an equal footing with the current Nicaraguan Government.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, since the last time we discussed Nicaragua in this Parliament last December, the situation in the country has not improved. Against the renewed pattern of persecution, harassment and intimidation, the European Union is following the possible adoption of the Law on Regulation of Foreign Agents and the Special Law on Cybercrimes, which could be used to tighten further the grip over civil society in Nicaragua. The draft foreign agents law in particular could be used to impose further restrictions on civil and political rights of individuals, civil society and on media outlets. It will also probably affect our cooperation programmes as well as Nicaragua’s human rights obligations and commitments. Since the beginning we have followed with utmost attention the tabling of the draft foreign agents law. On Tuesday our head of delegation in Managua, accompanied by all EU Member States present in the country, reached out to the Nicaraguan authorities in Managua at Minister of Foreign Affairs level to voice our concerns and find out more about the draft text, as well as to share our preoccupation on how the law would affect international human rights law and civil liberties in Nicaragua. The European Union has consistently voiced concerns against laws labelling NGOs as foreign agents all over the world. Nicaraguan citizens should be able to exercise their freedom of association effectively, and non-governmental organisations should operate in an environment conducive to the promotion and protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms. Civil society should operate free from hindrance and insecurity. Civil society organisations are essential actors for the promotion of human rights, good governance, democracy and the rule of law. The European Union comments and expresses its support for all individuals and organisations in Nicaragua who are still carrying out their legitimate and peaceful human rights work, despite the challenging circumstances in which they operate.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The next item is a debate on six motions for a resolution on the situation of Ethiopian migrants in foreign police cells in Saudi Arabia (2020/2815(RSP)).

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: Author. – Madam President, thousands of migrants are locked up in inhumane conditions and are victims of torture and rape in detention centres in Saudi Arabia. The scandal has epped now, but unfortunately, at least since 2017, these mass arrests and expulsions are taking place, contrary to international humanitarian law; an international law that Saudi Arabia is an expert in violating and ignoring, armed by the United States and often also by the European Union. In fact, just a week ago, Mr Borrell met with the Saudi authorities, but apparently, according to his press release, he forgot to mention precisely this situation that we are talking about here in Parliament. Saudi Arabia's illegal immigration policy is another example of the many human rights violations in Saudi Arabia. But as this happens, Europe ⸺this Europe⸺ still selling it weapons and offers cooperation agreements. Once again we demand strong action and not just beautiful words: arms embargo, immediate release of all immigrants and human rights defenders imprisoned in Saudi Arabia. Let us take note and make, above all, concrete policies.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: Author. – Madam President, tomorrow Parliament will send a strong message condemning the situation of Ethiopian immigrants, workers who are in a terrible situation locked up in camps in Saudi Arabia, but it is a resolution that goes far beyond that: we will also deal with systematic human rights violations in that country; we need to talk about human rights defenders, about the situation of women, and the text talks about it; we also talked about the un punishment for those responsible for the crime and murder of Mr Jashogui, of the situation of Raif Badawi, who by the way is the Sakharov Prize of this house. It is totally intolerable that, in the face of such a serious human rights situation, the countries of the European Union will continue to have such a systematic arms trade with this country.  Two things to end my speech: the first, the Resolution will call for the European institutions to lower the level of participation in the G20; we don't want the President of the Council or the Commission there. And finally, I have to tell the People's Party that, after the scandal they set up with Venezuela yesterday in plenary, that they have not been able to sign this resolution, frankly, it is a double standard of human rights that is frankly intolerable.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: Author. – Madam President, reports of torture, degrading treatment and even death to which Ethiopian migrants, including women and children, are exposed in Saudi Arabia, arbitrarily detained in overcrowded centres, where sanitary conditions, water and food are lacking, when they escape being slaughtered crossing the border, a scenario that persists in time and has been aggravated by the pandemic. All this in a country where the death penalty is in force and which has been the author of repeated human rights trampling, as are the cases of Mr Khashoggi, Mr Badawi and so many other resolutions in this Parliament in the past. We do not forget Moria, within our borders, and we will not turn to the tragedy of the 30,000 Ethiopian migrants detained in Saudi Arabia and the many other victims of human rights violations. We condemn the inothermite treatment of these migrants and call for their swift release.  The European Union must give clear signals in its relationship with Saudi Arabia by reducing diplomatic representation at the next G20 summit organised in that country and cease cooperation agreements, as well as put an end to the sale of material that can be used for surveillance or repression of the population. It is also necessary to support Ethiopia in creating the conditions for a decent and safe voluntary return of these migrants.

name: Urmas PAET
text: author. – Madam President, the situation of the Ethiopian migrants in detention centres in Saudi Arabia is deplorable. Thirty thousand people held in dire conditions in ten centres in Saudi Arabia, after escaping the crossfire from Houthi and Saudi forces on the border.  They lack water and food, the sanitary conditions are appalling and they have no medical care, with tuberculosis and other diseases rapidly spreading. Saudi Arabia needs to immediately release all detainees and transfer them to facilities where they have access at least to the basics: food, water, medical services, sanitation and space.  The torture and ill-treatment in the detention centres must stop immediately and an investigation must be conducted into all allegations of human rights violations. International monitors must be given access to monitor the situation there, and Ethiopian migrants must be provided a safe and dignified repatriation, in cooperation with the International Organization for Migration (IOM). As human rights are, and must be, at the core of the EU’s external policy, the EU and Member States must raise this issue also with Saudi Arabia most urgently. I think that it’s also necessary to downgrade EU institutional and diplomatic representation at the upcoming G20 leaders’ summit to send a clear message that this kind of treatment is not acceptable.

name: Isabel WISELER-LIMA
text: Author. Madam President, it is important that we talk about the appalling laws, because they are incredibly discriminatory, against women in Saudi Arabia. It is important that we talk about human rights defenders and political prisoners whose rights are being violated in this country. It is important that we condemn corporal punishment of another age and the application of the death penalty in this country. It is important that the European Parliament immediately address the overall human rights situation in Saudi Arabia. I will ask my colleagues, legal coordinators, to be one of our next topics on the agenda. Today, a resolution entitled "The situation of Ethiopian migrants in detention centres in Saudi Arabia" is on the agenda. I will therefore limit myself to this resolution and the migration problems associated with it. It will also be only on those points that my vote will be. Let me simply add that we should go far beyond the subject under consideration, there is no shortage of choices. Other detention centres around the world where migrants are being held in abominable conditions would have deserved our attention. Among the migrants in Saudi Arabia, Ethiopians are undoubtedly the ones with the most difficult living conditions. Often already victims of smugglers making them cross Yemen, once they arrive, they are exploited, underpaid and often at the mercy of their employer under the kafala system, a system that amounts to a situation of modern slavery. Now rejected because of the COVID-19 pandemic, thousands of Ethiopian migrants find themselves in even greater distress without resources or livelihoods.  Equally destitute are Ethiopians deported by the thousands from Yemen to Saudi Arabia. As Ethiopia is unable to repatriate its nationals, they find themselves on standby, detained and held by the hundreds in camps with inhumane living conditions, in enclosed places, often infected with the COVID virus or otherwise abused. And this for weeks, if not for months. Among them are particularly vulnerable people, such as children or pregnant women. All of this is simply unsustainable.  That is why we call on the Ethiopian authorities to repatriate their nationals as soon as possible and for Saudi Arabia to ensure that its detention centres comply with international standards and that migrants under their authority are not subjected to any ill-treatment, torture or sexual abuse.  We call on the European Union not only to warn about these inhumane conditions of detention, but also to use all diplomatic and political levers to try to stop them. Finally, I would like to affirm our support for the Global Migration Pact of the United States, which promotes standards for host countries to protect human rights, especially those of vulnerable groups.

name: Seán KELLY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, like many more I’m very concerned about the various reports of inadequate and inhumane conditions at the detention centres in Saudi Arabia for Ethiopian migrants. The migrants from Ethiopia and other countries, who had been working in northern Yemen but were forced out by the Houthi rebels, now face unimaginable cruelty, including being chained together in pairs and using their cell floors as toilets.  Saudi Arabia has also been cracking down on illegal migrants, with at least 10 000 Ethiopians on average being deported each month. But earlier this year Ethiopian officials requested a moratorium because of the coronavirus pandemic, the news agency AFP reports.  The EU should work with the Ethiopian authorities to help create enough space and quarantine facilities to welcome people back, to ensure they are not bringing coronavirus with them and that if individuals are repatriated to their home countries, it should be done in a dignified way. So therefore, we are calling on Saudi Arabia to fulfil its promise to launch an investigation into the allegations of cruelty in the detention centre.

name: Maria ARENA
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Madam President, the Saudi government has spent billions of dollars as part of a communications strategy to improve its image with the international community. But make no mistake, Saudi Arabia's human rights record is deplorable. The brutal murder of Jamal Khashoggi by Saudi agents did not result in any high-ranking responsibility for the murder. While Prince Mohammed bin Salman is trying to restore his image through communication efforts, the Saudi authorities are ordering waves of arbitrary arrests of dissidents, activists, intellectuals and members of the royal family. No wonder then that the conditions of migrants, mainly Ethiopian, are dramatic in this country, which ultimately does not know what human rights mean. No, it will not be enough to invite stars of culture or sport, nor to host the G20 to hide atrocities and human rights violations in Saudi Arabia. But by participating in this strategy, we Europeans are complicit, which is why we are asking to 'retrograde' the European Union's participation in the G20 and to send clear political messages to Saudi Arabia in all relations we have with Saudi Arabia to put the issue of human rights first.

name: Samira RAFAELA
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, imagine the cruelty of being put in detention camps with thousands and thousands, chained with no roofs and using cell floors as your bed. For migrant workers from Ethiopia in search of a better future, this is the day-to-day reality. In the past six months, at least 30 000 migrants have been put into these cruel, inhumane conditions. Human rights organisations report cases of deaths due to inhumane treatment, and these men, women and children have the right to have a dignified life. They have the right to safely return to their homes. The EU should call upon the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia to respect international law and immediately improve conditions. The EU should call upon the Ethiopian government to respect the citizens’ rights and urgently facilitate the voluntary repatriation of its nationals, and I call upon the European Commission to provide support to Ethiopians voluntarily returning home from Saudi Arabia and to send diplomatic representatives from the EU to visit the detention camps.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ID group. - Madam President, there are hundreds of them: men, pregnant women and children, confined to a single prison cell in a pestilential filth breathing death and disease. Those who try to escape are sometimes subjected to torture and summary executions. This is what the 16,000 Ethiopian migrants, proud descendants of the Queen of Saba in Saudi jails, are reduced to. Beyond the excitement, let us recognize that we Westerners are aware of the often deplorable treatment of migrants by some Arab-Muslims whose atrocities are extreme cases. Is it not hypocritical to speak out against kafala today, when the 2022 World Cup was awarded in Qatar in 2010, the use of this form of quasi-slavery was widely known. The tragedy of Ethiopian migrants illustrates the double standards that govern the global migration crisis. On the one hand, a Europe called upon to open its doors to a human tide from Africa or the Middle East, on the other the assumed inhumanity and cynicism of the Gulf States, which reject their own co-religionists, notably the Syrians, and expel manu militari, at a rate of 10,000 per month for Ethiopian nationals.  This tragedy demonstrates the impasse in the development of so many sub-Saharan African states, caught between the population explosion and the lack of economic opportunities. In Ethiopia, at the end of 2018, there were 2.9 million internally displaced people, with no lasting solution. With the energy of despair, many will grow the ranks of exile candidates, sometimes at the cost of their lives and freedom.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: – Madam President, the situation of Ethiopian migrants in Saudi Arabian prison is just the last episode of a long list of human rights violations in the country. Since March, over 30 000 people, including pregnant women and children, have been arbitrarily detained in unthinkable sanitary conditions. We are all aware of the importance of Saudi Arabia as a partner for the European Union and for the stability in the Middle East. However, this cannot be an excuse for the EU to ignore those violations. We all remember Jamal Khashoggi, Raif Badawi, Loujain al-Hathloul and the woman activists, and also Prince Salman bin Abdul Aziz and the Princess Basmah, arbitrarily detained for years. The EU cannot remain silent or use double standards. The sharing of our fundamental values and the respect of human rights must be an essential condition in our relations with third countries. For this reason, with this resolution we strongly urge President von der Leyen and Charles Michel to reconsider, or downgrade, the EU participation in the G20 summit in November. And finally, this would be an opportunity for the EU to show coherence with its values and not to legitimise impunity for the crimes committed in Saudi Arabia.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, my colleagues High Representative Borrell and Commissioner Lenarčič are travelling to Addis Ababa with the last EU humanitarian air bridge flight.  This humanitarian air bridge flight is very specific in its nature as it aims at bringing support to the African Union and the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention to be further distributed in African countries. It will be the third and last shipment to Addis, the most significant one, and also the last humanitarian air bridge flight organised by the European Union jointly with Germany. Besides the COVID—19 component, the joint visit to Addis is extremely timely. Regarding the African Union, it will be an opportunity to keep the momentum of a strengthened European Union-African Union partnership despite the postponement of the summit. With Ethiopian partners, it will be an opportunity to express our concerns over the political situation in the run—up to the elections. We have seen the shocking reports about African migrants, mainly Ethiopians, reportedly held under dreadful conditions in detention centres in Saudi Arabia. We also understand that earlier this week, eight Ethiopians died and 12 went missing off the coast of Djibouti after failing to reach Yemen. We knew already that the conflict in Yemen has created the world’s gravest humanitarian crisis. However, what we are discussing today shows that it also makes the situation of many migrants in the region close to unbearable. Despite the conflict, migration continues. The conflict in Yemen provides a fertile breeding ground for trafficking and smuggling networks, which profit from desperate African citizens looking for a better life in the Gulf. We are taking this situation seriously, and are following up and helping where we can. The EU delegation in Riyadh has raised the conditions in detention centres with the Saudi Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Labour rights and migration management are indeed issues we want to discuss more regularly with our Saudi interlocutors. There are indeed things to be said. Last week, High Representative Borrell received the Saudi Foreign Minister and reaffirmed the European Union’s interest in a structured human rights dialogue in which migration features prominently. We hope to launch this dialogue soon.  We are also reinforcing our engagement with the countries of origin in the Horn of Africa. Today, the High Representative and Commissioner Lenarčič are in Ethiopia. They will visit an International Organization for Migration transit centre where Ethiopian deportees, including from the Gulf, are quarantined upon arrival. We have recently provided EUR 60 million to the Horn of Africa Intergovernmental Authority (IGAD) to address the impact of COVID—19. This aid will also benefit migrants. We are eager to encourage a region—to—region dialogue on migration management between the Horn and the Gulf, as proposed by the Intergovernmental Authority on Development. We also hope that the soon—to—be—launched Red Sea Council can provide a platform for this. More broadly, in our external action we are committed to, and indeed an advocate for, the protection of the human rights of all migrants. The recently adopted EU Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy 2020—2024 calls for the protection of migrants, refugees and internally displaced persons. It also calls for support measures to improve integration and access to basic services. In our times of COVID—19 this is, of course, even more important. In third countries we strive to have migrants and forcibly displaced persons benefit from healthcare systems and include these groups in strategies related to COVID—19.
